LENGTH: 648 words

HEADLINE: Fiscal Shenanigans

 BODY:
President Bush appears to be planning to run for re-election as a tax cutter without discussing what federal programs will be sacrificed to make up for the lost revenue. That can't be allowed to happen. Voters have the right to see the whole picture, including the downside. Chances are they won't like the view. 
 While Mr. Bush has been out crowing about spending increases in some popular programs, his Office of Management and Budget was instructing federal departments to prepare to pare them down. In a May 19 memo that was first reported in The Washington Post, departments were told to trim domestic discretionary spending in 2006, the first complete fiscal year after the November election. And the administration recently submitted legislation to impose caps that would result in further reductions in every year after that through 2009. 
 According to estimates by the nonpartisan Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, the Office of Management and Budget guidelines translate into inflation-adjusted reductions in 2006 alone of about $925 million for Head Start and childhood education. That would come at a time when schools are already struggling to meet the demands of Mr. Bush's No Child Left Behind initiative without adequate resources. College financial aid, mainly Pell Grants, would take a $550 million hit -- at a time when lower-income students are dropping out of school because they cannot meet rapidly rising costs.
 The same projections show that veterans' medical care would be cut by $1.5 billion (after a planned $380 million cut in 2005). All told, under the proposed cuts, total funds for these and other affected programs -- like environmental protection, housing programs and nutrition aid for poor pregnant women and children -- would be $21 billion less in 2006 than today. By 2009, domestic discretionary spending, not counting homeland security, would be $45 billion below its current level and would be a smaller portion of the economy than it has been at any time since 1963.
 The budget-cutting exercise is undoubtedly inspired, at least in part, by complaints from conservatives about the enormous deficits being created by the White House's fiscal recklessness. They like the tax cuts, but want to match them with spending reductions. They have been demanding that the president start paring the budget, or at least demonstrate that he will be ready to do so after November.
 It's hard to imagine any realistic approach that would have the nation achieve fiscal responsibility with the tax cuts in place. First of all, even all of the proposed cuts in the memo would barely begin to make a dent in the annual deficits, which are likely to range from $300 billion to $400 billion for the rest of the decade. Second, although the fate of specific programs has not been decided, there is no way the administration can take a multibillion-dollar whack out of the relatively small budget for domestic discretionary programs -- a mere one-sixth of federal spending -- without hurting services that are both popular and desperately needed.
 Some of the staunchest tax-cut supporters in Congress are perfectly aware that the math doesn't work. They hope the accumulating pressure of the deficits will eventually force the federal government to go further and cut entitlement programs like Social Security, Medicaid and Medicare. Very few of them, however, are prepared to run for re-election on that plan.
 Currently, tax cuts since 2001 account for 17 times as much of the swing from surplus to deficit as do increases in domestic discretionary spending. No one who refuses to face up to the root cause of our fiscal problems should be permitted to seek public office without saying where the money will come from. Candidates who insist on keeping the Bush tax cuts -- whether they're running for Congress or the presidency itself -- have to show us the math.

HEADLINE: Bush Nominee to Lead F.T.C. Is Questioned Intensely About Gasoline Prices

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2 

 BODY:
Deborah P. Majoras, President Bush's choice to head the Federal Trade Commission, came under sharp questioning at a confirmation hearing on Wednesday by two Democratic senators who said the agency had not done enough to prevent a steep rise in gas prices.
 The senators, Ron Wyden of Oregon and Barbara Boxer of California, said that Ms. Majoras had failed to propose any meaningful change in the way the commission reviews oil company mergers and industry practices. They said this had contributed significantly to the recent run-up in prices at the pump, particularly on the West Coast. 
 The two senators also expressed frustration that the agency had not acted to stop the shutdown of a large refinery in Bakersfield, Calif., owned by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. The shutdown, they said, could prompt more price increases.
 Ms. Majoras is a former senior antitrust lawyer at the Justice Department who returned to private practice this year. Prodded by the two senators to describe what steps she might take to reduce gas prices, she said that she would talk to experts at the commission and examine any further reductions in refining in the United States. She also said she would appoint a special energy counsel at the agency to monitor the industry's practices.
 ''There is no question that refining capacity is extremely tight in the United States today,'' she said. ''I would want to look for reasons refineries are being shut down. I also want to look at why companies are not starting new refineries.''
 The two Democrats were not satisfied with her answers. And, Ms. Majoras may have hurt her cause when she acknowledged that this year she had done legal work for the ChevronTexaco Corporation. Under ethics rules, that could preclude her from being involved in some regulatory matters at the agency.
 ''If you are going to do two things -- talk to experts and look at the industry in general -- that is business as usual,'' Senator Wyden said. ''She still can't tell me how she'll get this agency off the sidelines and in the fight to protect American consumers or even whether she can participate.''
 He said he would try to hold off any action on her nomination, although it is unclear whether he has enough support from his colleagues to block her selection. 
 Congressional officials said Wednesday that while a number of Democratic senators were privately skeptical of the appointment, they had not said so publicly because the administration has coupled her nomination with that of Jon D. Leibowitz to become an F.T.C. commissioner. 
 Mr. Leibowitz, a former Democratic senior staff official in the Senate, is the head of the legislative office of the Motion Picture Association of America.
 But the Congressional officials said that if rising gasoline prices become more of a political issue for the administration, Ms. Majoras could encounter growing problems in the Senate. 
 Last week, the General Accounting Office issued a report concluding that industry consolidation during the 1990's had contributed to higher wholesale gasoline prices in the United States -- as much as 7 cents a gallon in California. The report's methodology was sharply criticized by Timothy J. Muris, who is stepping down as chairman of the commission this summer.
 Under both gentle and hostile questioning, Ms. Majoras refused to take a position on the report's conclusions. 
 In a Senate questionnaire that she was required to fill out before the hearing, Ms. Majoras took a limited view of her role as a regulator.
 ''The free market, the hallmark of our strong economic system, greatly benefits consumers,'' she wrote. ''Accordingly, in general, I favor market forces over extensive government regulation. Regulation can be costly and provoke unintended consequences.''
 She added, ''In the few instances in which a market or markets experience systemic failure that is not likely to self-correct, government regulation tailored to correct the failure may be appropriate, provided that careful analysis shows that the proposed regulation's expected benefits outweigh its expected costs.''

HEADLINE: Despite Surplus, City's Budget Is in Trouble, Monitors Warn

BYLINE: By MIKE McINTIRE

 BODY:
An improving economy is concealing serious problems in the city's budget that can only be solved through permanent spending cuts or increases in revenue, like higher taxes, a state fiscal monitor warned yesterday.
 The New York State Financial Control Board said it had reviewed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposed $46.9 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1, and found a ''deterioration in the city's fiscal condition that was temporarily masked'' by a growing surplus in this year's budget.
 The board, which can take control of the city's finances if the city ends the fiscal year with a deficit, said the city is relying too heavily on temporary increases to the personal income and sales taxes that are due to expire over the next two years.
 It said the projected surplus of about $1.5 billion this year would have been even larger if Medicaid costs, employee pensions and labor agreements had not increased. 
 ''On the surface,'' the board said in a report, ''a surplus of this size suggests that the city is in sound fiscal health. Unfortunately, the fact is the city's finances remain structurally unbalanced.''
 The control board's report is the latest in a series of warnings from budget watchers that the city's fiscal condition could be weaker than the numbers make it appear.
 Last week, the state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said he was ''increasingly concerned that rising interest rates and large federal deficits will put a damper on economic activity'' and squeeze New York City's budget.
 And the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported in April that the city is too dependent for its tax revenue on volatile Wall Street markets.
 Mr. Bloomberg has also warned that the city faces large deficits beginning in the 2006 fiscal year, and he has repeatedly stressed the problem of rising costs, some of which are beyond the city's control. But since he proposed spending $250 million to give a $400 property tax rebate to homeowners, the mayor has also sought to characterize the city's finances as improving enough to make the rebate fiscally responsible.
 The control board's report painted a starkly different picture. Citing the mayor's own estimate of a $3.8 billion deficit in 2006, the board suggested that the current surplus is little more than a fleeting break from the harsh reality of entrenched fiscal problems.
 The city, it said, is benefiting from a number of temporary measures, like $1 billion in soon-to-expire tax increases, $1.5 billion it borrowed to help recover from the Sept. 11 attacks, and a booming real estate market that since January has yielded $600 million more than expected from taxes on property transactions.
 The board urged the city to begin taking stronger ''recurring actions'' -- a euphemism for permanent spending cuts or revenue increases -- to close future gaps. Jeffrey L. Sommer, the acting executive director of the control board, said in an interview that even though the mayor's proposed budget for next year was balanced, he should start ''building up a surplus to use in 2006, because that is the troubled year.''
 The board, created in 1975 when the city was on the verge of bankruptcy, does not take a position on local policy initiatives, and so it would not publicly criticize the mayor's rebate plan or an alternative tax cut proposal by the City Council that could cost about $300 million. 
 Asked yesterday to comment on the board's report, Jordan Barowitz, a spokesman for the mayor, sought to blame any budget problems on the City Council. Mr. Barowitz pointed to a series of employee pension enhancements, discussed at a Council committee hearing yesterday, which he said would cost millions of dollars.
 David K. Chai, a spokesman for Gifford Miller, the Council speaker, said some of the pension changes were intended to benefit families of emergency services workers who died Sept. 11.

LENGTH: 1407 words

HEADLINE: Oracle Croons a New Tune About an Old Rival

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR; Laurie J. Flynn, in San Francisco, contributed reporting for this article.

 BODY:
In business, competitors are routinely cast as enemies to be fought and ridiculed. And over the years Oracle, led by its shoot-from-the-lip chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, has directed vast quantities of combative energy and invective at Microsoft -- a software maker led by a man even richer than Mr. Ellison, Bill Gates.
 But when Oracle squares off against the Justice Department over its proposed hostile takeover of PeopleSoft in Federal District Court in San Francisco next Monday, it will portray Microsoft as a guardian of competition and a welcome new entrant in the $25-billion-a-year global market for the back-office software that companies use to manage finances, human resources, procurement, sales and customer relations. 
 For Oracle, the new attitude toward Microsoft is not a change of heart but a matter of self-interest. The Justice Department is suing to block Oracle's $7.7 billion bid for PeopleSoft because it argues that the merger would be anticompetitive by reducing the number of major rivals in the business software market to two from three, thus driving up prices. PeopleSoft has rejected Oracle's offer several times; Oracle made its first offer in June 2003. 
 Oracle contends that the federal antitrust regulators have taken a myopic view to make their case, defining the market narrowly as confined to three suppliers: SAP of Germany, PeopleSoft and Oracle. The business software industry, Oracle insists, is a much broader, dynamic arena with no shortage of innovation and competitors. Microsoft is a prime exhibit in Oracle's defense. The world's biggest software company has risen rapidly, invested heavily and declared its goal of increasing its business software sales to $10 billion annually in less than a decade, from nearly $700 million last year. 
 In a white paper submitted to the Justice Department in late January, Oracle laid out its view of the Microsoft challenge in the business software market. Microsoft, according to the document, is a ''competitor'' and a ''committed entrant'' who is intent on changing the economics of the industry. ''It acts as a constraint on the exercise of any market power that might otherwise result from the combination of Oracle and PeopleSoft,'' the white paper said.
 The 29-page document, assessing Microsoft's progress to date and plans for the future, concluded: ''It is effective entry by a determined competitor, and Oracle welcomes the challenge. But entry it is, on a large scale and a short time line.''
 All antitrust merger cases require the courts to make a guess about the future, and in fast-changing technology that task is particularly tricky. 
 Judge Vaughn R. Walker must decide whether Microsoft's entry into the business software market is likely to be, in legal terms, ''timely'' and ''sufficient'' to reduce the market power of the incumbents. He must also determine if the market definition used by the Justice Department and supported by 10 states is appropriate. The government focused on two slices of the business-applications market -- financial and human-resource software -- sold to the largest corporations and government institutions.
 The Justice Department will begin calling witnesses on Monday, starting with Cox Communications and Verizon, both customers for software designed for large corporations. Later, the department is expected to call Douglas Burgum, a Microsoft senior vice president. 
 With Mr. Burgum's testimony, Justice Department lawyers hope to demonstrate that Microsoft will not move into the sophisticated software market for the largest corporations in the next two years. 
 Oracle, for its part, plans to call executives from I.B.M., Lawson, SAP and Siebel in hopes of showing that there are more than three competitors in the market. It also plans to call Cindy Bates, a Microsoft general manager. Oracle lawyers hope her testimony will reveal Microsoft's ambitions in the market. 
 The trial, which is expected to last a month, will require some intellectual gymnastics and selective loss of memory from both sides. Oracle moved into the business software market from its stronghold in corporate database software well before Microsoft. Its sales representatives have denigrated Microsoft's business software as suitable only for small and medium-size businesses, not heavyweight corporate use. In 2002, Charles Phillips, then an analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company, wrote, ''The back-office applications market for global companies is dominated by an oligopoly comprised of SAP, PeopleSoft and Oracle.'' Today, Mr. Phillips is the president of Oracle.
 Meanwhile, the Justice Department, in its long-running antitrust suit against Microsoft, depicted the company as a bullying predator, bent on moving beyond its monopoly in desktop operating systems into other software markets.
 Grabbing market share in software for corporate data centers is at the top of Microsoft's list of growth opportunities. Yet for the purposes of the Oracle case, the Justice Department has decided that Microsoft will confine its ambitions to small businesses and ''midmarket'' companies, which Microsoft defines as companies with up to 1,000 employees.
 Microsoft entered the business software market in December 2000, when it acquired Great Plains Software for $1.1 billion. In May 2002, it increased its presence with the purchase of Navision, a Danish software producer of business software, for $1.3 billion. Through investment, Microsoft has accelerated the growth of those businesses. By 2003, Microsoft rose to become the fourth-largest supplier of business software, according to IDC, a research firm. Microsoft had 2.9 percent of the broadly defined market for business software worldwide, well behind SAP, with 20 percent; PeopleSoft, with 7 percent; and Oracle, with 5.5 percent, IDC reported.
 Clearly, Microsoft has big plans for business software. In an interview last year, Orlando Ayala, a senior vice president, explained: ''There are very few businesses that can grow at a pace of 20 or 30 percent a year. We believe this business can be a $10 billion business.''
 Business software products also have a broader strategic importance for Microsoft. For nearly two years, the company has been developing a new generation of business software, code-named Project Green. The project involves nearly 700 programmers, at an estimated cost of more than $1 billion a year. Microsoft's business software is being rewritten to a single base of programming code, which is tailored to the company's .NET initiative. 
 The .NET technology involves a layer of software for distributed computing, linking all kinds of machines, using Internet standards. That technology is closely tied to Microsoft's Windows operating system, but it represents an effort to move Microsoft's dominance beyond personal computer software into everything from cellphones to corporate data centers.
 Microsoft's business software is seen within the company as crucial to the success of its .NET technology, just as the Microsoft Office suite of desktop programs was for Windows. In a presentation to industry partners in September 2002, a comment from Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, explained the strategy: ''Office is what drove the adoption of the Windows platform. Microsoft Business Solutions will drive the adoption of the .NET platform.'' Most of Microsoft's gains in business software have come with smaller companies, but it has won over some large corporations as well.
 Microsoft landed a sizable business software contract last year with Esselte, based in Stamford, Conn., a private producer and distributor of office supplies, with more than $1 billion in yearly sales and nearly 7,000 employees in 27 countries. 
 The company had 22 business software systems including those sold by SAP. Standardizing around SAP's systems might have been the logical step. But Lani Spund, a consultant brought in to overhaul the company's technology systems after an investment firm purchased Esselte in 2002, took a different route. 
 Mr. Spund said he ultimately chose Microsoft's Axapta system because it was flexible, could be expanded to handle Esselte's plans for rapid growth, and was half the price per employee of SAP's product.
 ''This is showing that Microsoft can be a player in the top end of the enterprise market,'' said Mr. Spund, who is now Esselte's chief information officer.

But the attempted takeover of PeopleSoft has brought out a kinder, gentler side of Mr. Ellison, at least for now. (Photographs by Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: The acquisitive MDC Partners expands again, this time buying a stake in Bruce Mau Design.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE acquisitive MDC Partners in Toronto -- the little agency company that could, or thinks it could -- is at it again, expanding into the rapidly growing field of design for marketing communications.
 MDC, which since January has bought interests in a half-dozen agencies including Cliff Freeman & Partners, Henderson Bas, Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners and Mono, is buying a majority stake in Bruce Mau Design, a well-regarded shop also based in Toronto.
 Mau Design, named after its founder, who has collaborated with the likes of Frank Gehry and Rem Koolhaas, specializes in services that are of growing interest to marketers seeking to reach consumers through methods beyond traditional advertising like television commercials.
 Mau Design creates everything from store layouts and signs to packaging and logos, helping to form and change attitudes about brands, products and retailers. 
 ''Design is setting the tone for all other communication to happen,'' Bruce Mau, who continues as chairman of Mau Design, said in a phone interview yesterday. 
 Miles S. Nadal, chairman and chief executive of MDC, said that Mau Design would become the core of a design specialty for his agency company, which is seeking to compete against its far larger rivals by promoting its offerings as fresher and more creatively focused.
 ''Design is becoming exceedingly important in the media mix,'' Mr. Nadal said, ''and we think there's a huge strategic value to offering that service to clients.''
 That is particularly true, he added, as ''the retail environment makes more of an impact'' on sales than previously. In the past, the primary influence on consumers was the advertising from marketers they saw and heard before they shopped. Now, chains like Bed Bath & Beyond, Best Buy, Home Depot and Wal-Mart lure shoppers with displays, events, promotions and other attractions in the stores -- appeals that may persuade shoppers to buy something different from what the traditional ads suggested.
 Mr. Nadal discussed the deal with Mau Design at a breakfast yesterday in Midtown Manhattan. The agreement, for MDC to acquire a 50.1 percent stake, is to be formally announced today, with an expansion into public relations and corporate communications to follow soon.
 Services besides traditional advertising bring ''a different sensibility to a brand that enhances the brand's presence,'' said Chuck Porter, chief strategist at MDC, who joined Mr. Nadal for the breakfast. 
 Mr. Porter, who is also chairman of one of the most prominent MDC agencies, Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, is the point person for the lengthening list of deals MDC is making; he recently returned from a scouting foray in Europe, where he had discussions with agencies that included Strawberry Frog.
 Mr. Mau, 44, said he had also ''been approached by several of the bigger groups,'' referring to the agency companies larger than MDC, ''but I thought they didn't add much to me because they wanted me to become like them.''
 ''What's exciting about this,'' he added, referring to the deal with MDC, ''is they're becoming like me.''
 Mr. Mau spoke from Vancouver, British Columbia, where he was working on a project for the Vancouver Art Gallery centered on a touring exhibition, titled ''Massive Change,'' on the potential and power of design.
 ''A friend of mine who works in the agency business said that 20 years ago, design was not meeting with the C.E.O.,'' Mr. Mau said, ''but today, design is at the head table.''
 ''We think of design as objects and spaces,'' he added, ''but more and more, we live inside a design environment and have developed the capacity to design our lives.''
 Mr. Mau lists clients and projects for Mau Design that include Indigo Books and Music, the largest Canadian book retailer; the Museum of Modern Art in New York, for graphics for the redesigned building that is to reopen in the fall; showrooms and sales brochures for the furniture maker Knoll; Mr. Koolhaas, the architect, for the book ''S, M, L, XL''; and Mr. Gehry, the architect, for graphics for the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles.
 On the public relations front, Mr. Nadal said, MDC is hiring Harry Clark, a longtime senior executive in the corporate affairs and lobbying fields, to help ''build a network of public relations, corporate communications and public affairs businesses.''
 Mr. Clark was a former partner in Clark & Weinstock, an agency now owned by the Omnicom Group in New York, the world's largest agency company with $8.6 billion in revenue last year.
 MDC, by contrast, will have about $320 million in revenue from marketing services this year, Mr. Nadal estimated, with a goal of $1 billion in five years as it continues acquiring agencies with entrepreneurial bents like Mau Design, Freeman and Kirshenbaum Bond.
 ''We're not Omnicom's size,'' Mr. Nadal said, ''but entrepreneurs like the idea of being around the table with like-minded people.''
 Entrepreneurs who like entrepreneurs like MDC? It could be a slogan, if Dial soap had not been there first with a similar sentiment.

HEADLINE: The Pied Piper of Las Vegas Seems to Have Perfect Pitch

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS 

 BODY:
Every dream needs a merchant, every myth a mythmaker. In Las Vegas, that job falls to Billy Vassiliadis, adman, huckster, deal maker and fixer extraordinaire.
 Friends and rivals alike describe Mr. Vassiliadis -- known universally as Billy V. -- as the most powerful unelected person in Nevada. The modifier may be superfluous. He has spun sand into pure gold.
 Mr. Vassiliadis is president and majority owner of R&R Partners, Nevada's largest advertising agency and the $65-million-a-year mouthpiece of the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority. His mission is to sell Las Vegas to the world, to keep the dreamers, the revelers, the suckers coming. 
 Mr. Vassiliadis has provided the background music as the city continually reinvents itself, alternately tarting itself up and toning itself down. The agency has sold the city as the ''Resort Bargain of the World,'' as ''The American Way to Play,'' as ''Open 24 Hours'' and, for a brief unshining moment in the mid-1990's, as a wholesome family destination.
 But the latest R&R Partners campaign, known in-house as ''Vegas Stories'' but to the world by its now-famous tagline, ''What happens here stays here,'' is destined to be long remembered as a stroke of marketing genius.
 The television spots are highly suggestive -- a group of young women in a limousine giggling over some unspoken exploit, a disheveled couple who have misplaced their luggage, a young man asking for a wake-up call to be directed to his cellphone. The message is unmistakable: In Las Vegas, anything goes.
 This is Billy Vassiliadis's Las Vegas. He is, metaphorically speaking, a sidewalk shill for the monstrous billion-dollar theme hotels rising from the hard-packed sands of the neon-drenched Strip, enticing one and all to try their luck. He looks the part, too, favoring dark slacks and sweaters, sporting rich salt-and-pepper hair, a single gold chain around his neck.
 But Mr. Vassiliadis, 48, is much more than a high-end huckster. He is a master player in almost every major game in Nevada -- politics, government, advertising, public relations, entertainment and gambling. His client list at R&R includes home builders, miners, ranchers, liquor distributors, hospitals, airlines, utilities, telecommunications firms and the big casino hotels on the Strip.
 He is an adviser to governors and senators, a political consultant and campaign guru, one of the most influential lobbyists in the state capital and a behind-the-scenes eminence in the state's economic engine, the euphemistically named resort industry.
 He is profane, sarcastic, loud, charming, bombastic, seductive, terrifying and a lot of fun to be around. He is a devoted husband, a father of two teenagers and the chief salesman for the after-midnight side of Las Vegas. He is, by his own description, ''schizo'' about living in Las Vegas, which is at once the nation's adult amusement park and a growing city where thousands of people arrive each month looking for jobs, houses, schools and churches, the trappings of a normal life. His job is to oil the engine that keeps them coming, the multibillion-dollar gambling and entertainment complex that provides the jobs and pays the taxes.

In Charge of 'What Happens Here'
 Asked to describe his mission in life, Mr. Vassiliadis does not hesitate. ''What I do for a living is I try to promote and protect the state's largest industry,'' he said in an interview in his office surrounded by pictures of himself with Bill Clinton and other politicians, and trinkets from his beloved Chicago Cubs and Bears. ''My job is to drive as much demand for this destination as I can.''
 The ''Vegas Stories'' campaign, by all available measures, is doing just that. A record 35 million visitors passed through Las Vegas last year, and the city seems poised to set another record this year.
 The ''What happens here'' tagline has become a fixture in the popular culture, appearing in prime-time series and on ''Saturday Night Live'' and ''Today.'' 
 William J. Bennett, the education secretary in the Reagan administration, complained after he was caught on a surveillance camera in a Las Vegas casino, ''Apparently, 'What happens here, stays here' applies to everyone but me.''
 Manuel Cortez, the president of the convention bureau and a onetime political client of Mr. Vassiliadis's, is delighted with the current campaign. ''It's suggestive, yes, but there's nothing you can see that's pornographic,'' he said. ''Las Vegas is what it is. Las Vegas is an adult playground. That is one of the keys to attracting ever-increasing numbers of conventions and trade shows.''
 Five years ago, the convention authority put its lucrative advertising contract up for bid. National firms competed, but R&R blew them away with a gaudy video that was pure Vegas showmanship. The convention authority just renewed R&R's contract for five more years without bidding it out. Mr. Cortez has no apologies. ''We're in the middle of a campaign that's better than anything we've ever had,'' he said.
 Of Mr. Vassiliadis he said, ''Billy is very, very well respected in the industry,'' using, perhaps without meaning to, a phrase that in Las Vegas has long implied well connected to the mob. ''He's a guy you want in your corner if you have a problem -- a political problem or a marketing problem.''
 Billy Vassiliadis was 18 when he arrived in Las Vegas in the 1970's, a big outgoing Greek kid from Chicago. He was born in Athens. His father taught in Greek Orthodox schools in Greece, Romania and Ethiopia before immigrating to the United States in 1957 with his wife and year-old son. He attended the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, where he became active in Democratic politics and began cultivating friends and mentors who would catapult him into prominence.
 ''What was great about Vegas then and to a large extent is still true, was opportunity,'' Mr. Vassiliadis said. ''Anybody who has talent and a passion to succeed is just not going to fail here.''
 He volunteered on numerous campaigns and in 1982 ran the long-shot campaign of John Moran for the job of Clark County sheriff. Mr. Moran won.
 At the end of 1982, Sig Rogich offered Mr. Vassiliadis a job in his agency, R&R Partners. The agency already had the Las Vegas convention authority contract and represented Howard Hughes's casino hotels, home builders and car dealerships.
 ''Billy became my right arm,'' said Mr. Rogich, 60. ''We were really the odd couple. Sometimes he'd shave, sometimes he wouldn't. His office was always a great mess. It used to drive me crazy.''
 Having Mr. Vassiliadis around freed Mr. Rogich to devote time to national politics. After directing advertising for the 1988 and '92 Bush campaigns, he returned to Las Vegas, and barely recognized the agency he had founded. Mr. Vassiliadis had remade it in his own image: splashier, more aggressive, deeply involved in Nevada politics.
 ''It wasn't necessarily bad, just different,'' Mr. Rogich said. ''They just weren't my people.'' He decided to sell to Mr. Vassiliadis and several other partners, a decision he came to regret.
 ''I had seller's remorse,'' Mr. Rogich admitted. ''I made a lot of money but I missed the creative part, the electricity.''

A Broad Sphere of Influence
 Under Mr. Vassiliadis, the firm has grown to 220 employees and more than $200 million a year in billings. It occupies its own year-old 70,000-square-foot building in Summerlin, a prosperous suburb.
 The offices reflect Mr. Vassiliadis's personality, self-consciously hip, with the feel of an adult game arcade, all open space with 14-foot-video screens, table tennis and a foosball game in the common area. The first-floor conference room, called the War Room, is painted in camouflage and decorated with a four-foot-tall hand grenade.
 As Mr. Vassiliadis cemented control of R&R, he was also expanding his political and business portfolio. He ran the two governor's campaigns of Bob Miller, the son of Ross Miller, a casino operator connected to the Chicago organized-crime outfit. He also pushed along the political career of Mr. Cortez, who served 16 years on the Clark County Commission before becoming president of the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority a decade ago, a relationship that has paid Mr. Vassiliadis huge dividends.
 There is hardly a figure in statewide or national politics in Nevada today who does not owe some debt to Billy Vassiliadis.
 Nevada's 1988 Senate campaign became an occasion for one of Mr. Vassiliadis's notorious eruptions of temper. He had become close to Jon Ralston, then the political writer for The Las Vegas Review-Journal and now a columnist for The Las Vegas Sun and host of a television political talk show. Although Mr. Miller, then the lieutenant governor, was not running, his father's ties to the mob became an issue in the race. Mr. Vassiliadis, fighting back on behalf of the Democratic Senate candidate, Richard Bryan, tried to plant a story with Mr. Ralston about the supposed Watergate connection of a Republican aide on the other side in the race.
 Mr. Ralston refused to bite, and Mr. Vassiliadis turned on him with a fusillade of high-volume invective.
 ''An hour after he blew up at me he called back and said, 'Do you still love me?'''
 Now they talk almost daily. ''We're closer than most brothers are,'' Mr. Ralston said.
 As he built his political client base, Mr. Vassiliadis also became one of the two or three most powerful lobbyists in Carson City. His most important lobbying account is also the state's most important interest group -- the Nevada Resort Association, representing the 15 big casino companies that dominate gambling in the state.
 Mr. Vassiliadis is a rich man many times over, but he turned down as clients cigarette makers, strip clubs and insurance companies. He also turned away the nuclear waste industry, which is seeking to build a high-level radioactive dump in Nevada. ''That was retirement money,'' he said.
 Jan Jones, a former mayor of Las Vegas who ran for governor against Mr. Miller in 1994, said Mr. Vassiliadis is wired into the state's power structure.
 ''Is he the most powerful non-elected person in Nevada? Oh, absolutely,'' she said. ''You would call him before you call the governor, because Billy will get you there and your name won't be in the newspaper.''
 ''What happens here, stays here'' was the handiwork of two young R&R copywriters, Jeff Candido and Jason Hoff, who have moved on to agencies on the East Coast. It is indelibly associated with Mr. Vassiliadis and could well end up as his ironic epitaph.
 The phrase is not universally loved. Some civic boosters say it perpetuates a tawdry image when they are trying to sell Las Vegas as a healthy place to raise a family.
 Mr. Vassiliadis said even his wife of 20 years, Rosemary, who comes from a conservative Catholic family in Chicago, is less than enamored of the campaign and the image it projects. Billy V. shrugs. The campaign, and the city, are about a visceral feeling of freedom, an emotional need to escape, he said. And the way you sell that is to suggest that life here is fundamentally different from life elsewhere.
 ''People come here and lose themselves in their own notion of what personal freedom is,'' he said. ''It's not so much outlaw or naughty. It's not about having sex. It's about coming here and feeling sexy, feeling like a high roller.''

AMERICAN DREAMERS
The Lure of Las Vegas
 Las Vegas is America's magnet city, an irresistible destination for countless pleasure-seekers and a vast tide of economic migrants. Articles in this series have examined the city and its suburbs through the lives of a few of the people who have pursued new beginnings there, including a teacher, a judge, a stripper, a waitress and an advertising man.

HEADLINE: Costs Put Delta in the Cross Hairs of Crisis

BYLINE: By MICHELINE MAYNARD

 BODY:
Before the September 2001 terrorist attacks, Delta Air Lines perennially led the airline league, with lower costs than competitors like American or United and plenty of loyal customers. 
 The company's costs have barely risen since then, which in another industry might be something to brag about. But for Delta, it is a big problem -- and the main reason why it is the latest major airline to be swept by a financial crisis.
 As airline chief executives pleaded for help in a Congressional hearing yesterday, Wall Street began to worry that Delta could decline much more swiftly than anticipated.
 Even so, Representative John L. Mica, the Florida Republican who heads the House aviation subcommittee, told the executives that the airlines would have to ''fend for themselves'' and could not expect any more significant help from the government. 
 ''Congress is not going to underwrite losing airline operations,'' Mr. Mica said.
 The airline in the spotlight right now is Delta, which for years was considered one of the soundest and best managed of the majors. On May 10, the airline said it might have to file for bankruptcy protection unless it could slash costs and win steep concessions from its pilots' union.
 Many of Delta's rivals have managed to cut their costs by double-digit percentages in the years since the terrorist attacks by going that route -- either filing for bankruptcy protection, like United, or threatening to file, like American. In the process, they erased Delta's onetime efficiency advantage, leaving it with what are now among the highest costs in the industry. 
 Then jet fuel prices began to skyrocket, climbing by nearly half in the last year, and stiff competition from low-fare carriers has kept everyone in the industry from recouping the higher costs through increases in ticket prices. Together, the developments have put fierce pressure on Delta. 
 In recent days, the airline has reinforced its warning about the state of its finances by hiring restructuring advisers to identify ways to streamline its debts and its operations. 
 ''It is Delta's moment,'' said Michael Allen, chief operating officer of Back Aviation, an industry consulting firm.
 Jamie Baker, who follows airlines for J.P. Morgan, reported yesterday that he expected Delta to lose $7.78 a share in 2004, almost 60 percent more than his previous estimate of $4.93. Mr. Baker said the airline could be in Chapter 11 by the end of the year. 
 That Delta feels obliged to talk about a bankruptcy filing is sobering for the industry, experts said, demonstrating that however well run an airline has been, none can afford to stand still in today's troubled business environment. And there is no relief in sight from the twin pressures on costs and revenues.
 ''The fear is that this is a lasting problem that they will have to deal with,'' said Philip A. Baggaley, an airline analyst with Standard & Poor's.
 Mr. Baggaley, who testified at yesterday's hearing, said that this should have been a good year for the airlines. The economy is healthy, many flights are full and summer traffic volume is expected to be the strongest since 2001. Yet the Air Transport Association, an industry trade group, estimates airlines will lose $3 billion in 2004.
 Why? Airline executives have a uniform answer: jet fuel, which costs more than $1 a gallon, compared with about 76 cents last June. While some airlines have insulated themselves from part of the impact through hedging contracts, others did not, or in United's case could not, because of its December 2002 bankruptcy filing. 
 United now expects its fuel bill for the year to run $750 million over its forecast, complicating its bid for a $1.6 billion package from the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, created by Congress after the Sept. 11 attacks to oversee $10 billion in loan guarantees and other assistance.
 Yesterday, the board's executive director, Michael Kestenbaum, said the federal government owned stakes equivalent to $100 million in six airlines that received loan guarantees totaling $1.8 billion.
 Airlines say the damage from fuel costs would not be so severe if they could pass the costs along to consumers by charging higher fares, as they were able to do when oil prices spiked in the past. Not this time, though. Numerous attempts by Continental, Northwest and other carriers to raise fares by $5 to $20 a ticket have largely failed, because low-fare airlines flying the same routes undercut them.
 The ease with which consumers can comparison shop on travel Web sites has also hindered the airlines' efforts to raise fares, Mr. Allen said. ''There is no pricing power,'' he added.
 That leaves the airlines little choice but to find more cost cuts across their businesses. Delta, with more than $20 billion of debt on its balance sheet, has been conducting a complete strategic review since the beginning of the year. 
 The chief executive, Gerald A. Grinstein, wants to present a restructuring plan to Delta's board late in the summer. To develop it, Delta has retained the Blackstone Group, a specialist in debt restructuring, and Davis, Polk & Wardwell, a law firm it has used on financial matters, according to people who had been briefed on the matter. Delta executives said the company routinely got advice from legal and financial experts and declined to discuss which advisers it had retained.
 Mr. Allen said Delta's efforts were meant to communicate a sense of urgency, like the one American created a year ago when it repeatedly threatened to file for Chapter 11 protection if employees refused to accept wage and benefit cuts.
 ''If you drive as if you are going to run into the wall, that's when action takes place,'' he said. ''It will probably take coming very close to the edge before anything of a serious nature comes about.''
 But, Delta's pilots, whose contract expires next May, are not required to sit down with the company until Aug. 3. They have already rejected a Delta proposal to cut wages and benefits by 30 percent, saying 9 percent would be more acceptable. 
 Mr. Baggaley said Delta could cite its rivals as cautionary lessons in talks with the unions, because without concessions from workers, ''United would be shut down, American would be bankrupt, and Continental never would have come out of bankruptcy'' in the 1990's.
 For proof of the value of acting to pre-empt problems, Delta need only look to the industry's biggest low-fare carrier, Southwest Airlines. In addition to actively hedging its exposure to fuel prices, Southwest has been modifying its Boeing 737 jets by adding winglets, small extensions curving up and out from the wingtips, to reduce drag and save fuel. 
 Southwest considered the move for years, but was loath to take its tightly scheduled planes out of service for several days each to install them. 
 Last year, though, when it seemed that jet fuel might climb over 80 cents a gallon, Southwest calculated that the time was right, said James C. Wimberly, an executive vice president and chief of operations.
 Now, it is adding winglets to 66 of its 162 Boeing 737-700 planes, at a rate of 10 to 12 a month, and is having them installed on all new jets it buys, Mr. Wimberly said this week. Southwest expects the winglets to cut fuel consumption by as much as 3.5 percent on each flight and save $2 million a quarter. ''We have been very, very happy with the performance,'' he said.
 Delta and its rivals must follow Southwest's example, forget about fare increases and focus relentlessly on cost-cutting, said Robert W. Mann Jr., an industry consultant based in Port Washington, N.Y. ''The only long-term answer is productivity improvements,'' Mr. Mann said.
 The time to make those improvements is short. Delta and the other majors ''have only what is left of this business cycle to implement changes and repair their balance sheets,'' he said. ''Those that fail will be unable to weather the next cyclical downturn.''

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section E; PT2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 30

LENGTH: 4663 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* ''BYZANTIUM: FAITH AND POWER (1261-1557),'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through July 4. This vast and humblingly beautiful show about the waning centuries of the Byzantine empire reminds us that political decay does does not necessarily mean artistic decline. Full of amazing exotica -- manuscripts, miniature mosaics, textiles, drawings, paintings -- the exhibition ends with a room of great Northern Renaissance art indebted to icons that proves Byzantium's continued reach. People who are not Eastern Orthodox believers can enjoy the earthly pleasures of aesthetic spectacle linked with historical enlightenment. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7 (Michael Kimmelman).

* ''GOLDEN FANTASIES: JAPANESE SCREENS FROM NEW YORK COLLECTIONS,'' Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, (212) 517-2742, through June 27. The painted folding screens in this small but splendiferous exhibition date from the 16th and 17th centuries, when a still-feudal Japan was undergoing major social and cultural changes. Both a ruling military elite and a rising mercantile bourgeoisie used art to create a dynamic and refined self-image. And few societies have produced power-objects more persuasive than the types of screens seen here, each a tour de force of high-end artifice. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

''MARIUS DE ZAYAS AND THE STIEGLITZ CIRCLE,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through June 27. This small show, focusing mainly on caricatures drawn by an associate of Alfred Stieglitz, is getting the jump on the 100th anniversary of the 1905 founding of Stieglitz's immensely influential Little Galleries of the Photo-Secession. De Zayas, an artist and later an art dealer himself from a celebrated Mexican family, drew images in charcoal and ink of Stieglitz and other photographers like Edward Steichen and Gertrude Kasebier and of artists like Max Weber and John Marin. They are always formally elegant and materially sumptuous, and some are almost illegibly abstract. Hours and admission: See above (Ken Johnson).

* ''MODIGLIANI: BEYOND THE MYTH,'' Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200, through Sept. 19. The first big New York retrospective of Modigliani since 1951, believe it or not, this is an overstuffed show that includes predictable duds but also a select group of his best sculptures and paintings, which belie the stereotype of him as an impulsive lunatic doing poster-ready art, hellbent on self-destruction. The good works indicate someone of worldly intelligence, patience, discipline and steady concentration. Modigliani's huge popularity has always depended on his risque reputation and on his languid, pretty, easily digested and unmistakable brand of delicately abstracted modernism. As with Chagall or Ben Shahn, it could frequently tip over into kitsch or parody. But at its best, it is original and exquisite and suggests someone beyond the bohemian cliche, clearly wrestling with issues besides the formal felicity of elongated shapes, who died prematurely. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m.; Fridays, to 3 p.m. Admission: $10; $7.50 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* ''PAINTERS OF REALITY: THE LEGACY OF LEONARDO AND CARAVAGGIO IN LOMBARDY,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Aug. 15. This show was partly conceived in scholar world, and it includes a few dull pictures that are here only to prove academic points you didn't know mattered in the first place. But don't let that obscure the exhibition's attraction, which has, above all, to do with discovery. You probably have never heard of many of the painters on view. Consider this an opportunity. Yes, you will find Leonardo and Caravaggio. But the visceral joy should come from happening on very great artists you might not know, with names like Savoldo, Lotto, Ceruti and Fede Galizia. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

''THE PIERRE AND MARIA-GAETANA MATISSE COLLECTION,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through June 26, 2005, in three installments. This heterogeneous array of paintings, sculptures and works on paper was once owned by the Manhattan-based art dealer Pierre Matisse (1900-1989) and his wife, Maria-Gaetana (1943-2001). Most of the material came to the Met after Mrs. Matisse's death. It includes sexy paintings by Balthus, Magritte and Wifredo Lam, batty ones by Jean Dubuffet, and a feminist icon in a self-portrait by Leonora Carrington. A selection of the rich, calm, pleasurable art of Henri Matisse, Pierre's father, takes pride of place. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* ''TREBLE,'' SculptureCenter, 44-19 Purves Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 361-1750, through Aug. 1. The most substantial manifestation of the New Sound, New York festival of sound art brings together the work of 22 artists and sound artists, effectively exploring the medium's infiltration of sculpture, Conceptual Art, Process Art and much more. It also makes brilliant use of the building's sometimes-soundproof construction, from Brad Tucker's found-nylon geodesic dome, to Jim Hodges's blown-glass bells to Andrea Ray's soothing oasis in the a basement vault, fashioned from very crunchy solar salt, yellow light and chanting voices. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 6 p.m. Free (Roberta Smith).

* ''FRED WILSON, OBJECTS AND INSTALLATIONS: 1979-2000,'' Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500, through July 4. Mr. Wilson, who represented the United States at the 2003 Venice Biennale, made his reputation with conceptually pointed, technically polished and visually engaging installations and objects that focused on excavating American racial history and illustrating the exclusionary power of cultural institutions shaped by social, economic and ideological domination. Elements of his subversive museum projects appear in this traveling show, along with sculptures and a fine, short new film. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; students and 62+, $3; children under 12, $1 (Cotter).

Galleries: Uptown

PIERRE BONNARD, Wildenstein, 19 East 64th Street, (212) 879-0500, through June 11. This very uneven show boasts one splashy painting, the large and lovely ''Landscape With a Blue Bird'' (1942) that shows Bonnard at his colorific best. Smaller oils, watercolors and drawings make up the rest of the show. Among the best of these are several very small landscape drawings, like ''The Open Window, With Mountains in the Distance,'' and ''Landscape at Arcachon,'' in which a tiny red-roofed house is nestled among green trees. Their loose but electric drawing, combined with touches of color, makes pure Bonnard magic (Grace Glueck).

''THE DEVONSHIRE INHERITANCE: FIVE CENTURIES OF COLLECTING AT CHATSWORTH,'' Bard Graduate Center, 18 West 86th Street, (212) 501-3000, through June 20. The stately English country home Chatsworth has been occupied since its construction in 1552 by the Cavendish family, headed by a long succession of dukes and duchesses of Devonshire. They have enriched it with notable collections of fine and decorative arts, an awesome library of books and manuscripts, scientific instruments, silver, furniture and needlework. A glimpse of these treasures is provided by this show, which has works by Rembrandt, Raphael, Titian, Durer and Lucian Freud; books and drawings by Andrea Palladio; a spectacular jewelry ensemble worn at the coronation of Czar Alexander II and much else to light up the eyes of the most jaded connoisseur. The next step is a visit to Chatsworth itself, still a private home for the
Cavendishes but very much open to the public (Glueck).

* ''GARDEN IN DELFT: WILLEM DE KOONING LANDSCAPES 1928-1988,'' Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 744-7400, through June 26. For the centennial of de Kooning's birth, this exhibition of 14 canvases represents a jubilant skip through his long career, with emphasis on his relationship to landscape. Never mind that the suggestion of abstracted still lifes sometimes seems equally strong, especially in two unfamiliar canvases from the late 1930's. A third painting, titled ''Still Life'' and dated circa 1929, may well be the earliest de Kooning painting most of us have ever seen. Its crisp shapes and deep primary colors suggest the influence of Joseph Stella and look forward to David Hockney (Smith).

STANLEY SPENCER, CDS Gallery, 76 East 79th Street, (212) 772-9555, through July 27. Religion, sex and his hometown of Cookham-on-Thames preoccupied the English painter Stanley Spencer (1891-1959), who expressed his visions in robust paintings that combined the influences of Italian Reniassance masters and modernist European movements. His powerful draftsmanship is seen in this show of 26 sheets that range from the early 1920's to the mid-1950's. Particularly evident is his adroitness at complex figural compositions, displayed in four studies for an unfinished painting, ''Christ Preaching at the Cookham Regatta.'' (One depicts four young men idling in a punt, a comment on the wealthy who attended the regatta along with common folk.) His softer erotic side is evident in a study for ''Leda and the Swan,'' a frothy vision of Leda in several poses, at first fighting off the bird, then submitting ecstatically. And there are a couple of wonderful portraits, a reflective early study of his wife, Hilda, and a jolly frumpish likeness of a Margaret Slesser, the wife of a judge in whose household he boarded in his early years. This catchall display, in which some of the works are faded and faint, lacks the oomph one expects from a Spencer drawing show, but it gives a taste of the artist's superlative skills applied to obsessive interests (Glueck).

ANTON VAN DALEN, ''The Living Room,'' Adam Baumgold, 74 East 79th Street, (212) 861-7338, through June 12. For his first solo show since 1996, this longtime East Village resident offers an engaging, cheerfully pluralistic 23-year retrospective. His always neatly made paintings, drawings and constructions look, variously, as if they were created by a savvy graphic designer, an idiosyncratic urban folk artist or a canny Conceptualist. They address topics like the history of the East Village art scene, sex, work, cars, drivers and the cultivation of pigeons (Johnson).

''WEEGEE'S STORY,'' Ubu, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444, through July 23. Wielding his 4-by-5 Speed Graphic with a master's touch, the New York tabloid photographer Weegee probably shot more murders and fires in his heyday, the 1930's and 40's, than anyone else in the business. But his passion for the city also drew him to its many other photo opportunities: the strivers and the homeless, festivities and freaks, politicians and celebrities, posh avenues and mean streets. This show of 220 Weegee vintage photographs, culled from a collection assembled over 30 years by the Berlin dealer Hendrik Berinson, reveals his remarkable range (Glueck).

Galleries: Chelsea

ANDREA CHAMPLIN/RACHEL URKOWITZ, Michael Steinberg, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 924-5770, through June 18. The two artists appear in separate rooms, but they share a devotion to energetically animated abstraction. Ms. Champlin's big, explosive paintings of pixilated, balloonlike volumes and other bulbous forms are based on digitally scrambled self-portrait photographs. Ms. Urkowitz makes lively collages on large, irregularly shaped sheets of paper, combining passages of Cubist crystallization, biomorphic Surrealism and trippy doodlelike forms. She also presents a series of goofy, free-standing sculptures: oversize cartoon daisies neatly laser-cut from sheets of colored plastic (Johnson).

* WILLEM DE KOONING, ''A Centennial Celebration,'' Gagosian, 555 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 941-1111, through June 19. This beautifully installed 40-work survey begins with several previously unexhibited late ribbon paintings with their wafting, tangling strands of color that intimate both landscapes and still lifes but are, above all, abstract. The presentation seems to argue that de Kooning, like his younger colleague Philip Guston, would still have ample art historical stature had he made no other paintings than these, produced during the decade before he descended into Alzheimer's disease. But the show then backtracks through most of the artist's development, making the counter argument by demonstrating the many divergent and crisscrossing paths he took to reach his final distillation (Smith).

* TONY FEHER, ''The Wart on the Bosom of Mother Nature,'' D'Amelio Terras, 525 West 22nd Street, (212) 352-9460, through July 2. Mr. Feher makes wryly poetic and visually enchanting sculptures out of the least promising of materials: plastic and glass bottles and bottle caps, foam packing material, bent wire, soda stacking crates, marbles, colored string, crushed aluminum foil and stones. A pyramid of green plastic strawberry baskets has a luminous, dematerialized look. A collection of brown bottles stopped by red and blue marbles is captivatingly sensuous and obliquely political (Johnson).

PIA FRIES, ''MurGang,'' CRG, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 229-2766, through June 12. Using palette knives, squeegees and extruding tools that she makes herself, this German artist applies paint in massive quantities to snowy white panels, creating viscerally attractive topographies of striated swathes, rippling ribbons, melting puddles and bristly thickets of brushstrokes. Looking closer you discover silkscreen photographs of earlier paintings underlying the actual paint, setting up dialogues between the mediated and the unmediated (Johnson).

EDGAR JERINS, Tatistcheff, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4547, through June 12. The dramatically lighted realist images that Mr. Jerins draws, in charcoal on sheets of paper measuring about 5 by 8 feet, look like scenes from novels by Russell Banks. There's an air of grim desperation in his self-portrait with his two daughters and his pregnant, exhausted-looking wife, posed in a cramped bedroom and subtitled, ''We Need to Move.'' The portrait of a hunter with a shotgun in his tidy living room -- with a little girl and two women, one pregnant -- projects an unsettling hint of possible violence (Johnson).

DOUG OHLSON, Andre Zarre, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 255-0202, through June 19. Pure formalism with an emphasis on color is not the most fashionable approach to painting these days, which makes Mr. Ohlson's pulsating stripe paintings all the more gratifying to behold. On horizontal canvases, the artist, who is 78, paints vertical bands, some hard-edged, some brushy, in shades that range from glowing sherbets to deep, near-black blues. He orchestrates a rich wedding of Puritanism and hedonism (Johnson).

* CLAES OLDENBURG AND COOSJE VAN BRUGGEN, ''Images a la Carte,'' Paula Cooper, 534 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1105, through July 2. Made mostly on blue-lined notebook pages the size of index cards, using pencil, ink and watercolor, these wonderfully lively and keenly observed drawings depict shrimp cocktails, crabcakes, salads, sandwiches, a banana split, tarts, cheesecakes and other elaborate restaurant fare, interspersed with simpler items like a lemon slice, an apple core and a piece of cornbread. Mr. Oldenburg drew them; his longtime partner, Ms. van Bruggen, contributed ideas (Johnson).

* DANIEL RICHTER, ''The Morning After,'' David Zwirner, 525 West 19th Street, (212) 727-2070, through June 19. The 11 large, dystopic works in the New York solo debut of one of Germany's hottest new painters fail to live up to expectation. The lurid fluorescents and toxic darks, the post-apocalyptic imagery and the polymorphous watercolorish painting techniques all have their moments, but they are mostly mashed together into a confused, essentially conservative pastiche. The ambiguities feel canned, suggestive of a few too many viewings of ''Blade Runner'' or ''A Clockwork Orange'' (Smith).

JEFF SCHER, ''MILK OF AMNESIA,'' Maya Stendhal, 545 West 20th Street, (212) 366-1549, through June 30. Mr. Scher's short animated films -- none longer than seven minutes -- are optical joyrides. He copies by hand all kinds of found film, including old cartoons, Hollywood movies and pornography, in different colors and degrees of abstraction and painstakingly shoots his own new cels one by one. Set to delightful musical soundtracks, these collages of constant metamorphosis are dazzling and mesmerizing to watch (Johnson).

''SYMMETRIES,'' Senior & Shopmaker, 21 East 26th Street, (212) 213-6767, through June 30. The four sculptors in this fine exhibition are like cousins with shared as well as divergent interests. The show features a vibrant and whirling new wall painting by Sol LeWitt; an elegant arrangement of three-dimensional geometrical elements by Barry LeVa; a surprising early Cubist assemblage of unfinished boards by Richard Artschwager; and a conflation of vernacular architecture and Constructivist sculpture by Siah Armajani
(Johnson).

* ''TERRORVISION,'' Exit Art, 475 10th Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 966-7745, through July 31. Terror comes in all sizes, shapes and degrees, and this show runs the gamut, with exhibits by some 50-odd artists facing up to their most ''extreme fears'' -- from the general threats posed by al Qaeda and its franchises to the traumas of personal catastrophe like toothache, breast cancer and heart operations. The gallery's multidisciplinary emphasis is manifest in film, video, audio and computer-generated creations, along with media as simple as prints and photographs. It's a mix of successful efforts and some that don't quite make it, the lightweight with the more substantial. But it's alive and kicking (Glueck).

Galleries: SoHo

''DOGS + CATS,'' American Primitive, 594 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212) 966-1530, through June 12. This lively exhibition includes more than 60 feline or canine representations in two or three dimensions. Some are by self-taught artists. A big colorful painting by Jean Metcalf has cats and dogs in it but features a formal parade of rats carrying wounded birds on stretchers. Many are by unknown craftsmen, like the smoothly carved wooden head of a boxer with brown glass eyes, and the functional dog-shaped bench in the form of a wooden slab with branches that have been turned into legs (Johnson).

ANISH KAPOOR, Barbara Gladstone, 515 West 24th Street, (212) 206-9300, through June 25. Mr. Kapoor is the master of a certain sculptural paradox. He makes abstract sculptures that are powerfully and often luxuriously physical but have an apparently immaterial dimension. The four concave sides of ''Whiteout'' bend inward to what seems an impossible extent. ''Vortex,'' a shiny black circle built into the wall, recedes inward like a whirlpool toward a deep, dark and apparently limitless space. The effect is hair-raising (Johnson).

GERHARD RICHTER, ''Two Sculptures for a Room by Palermo,'' Peter Freeman, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-5154, through June 26. Here is one of the very few sculptures made by Mr. Richter, the immensely influential German painter, during his career. It consists of two plaster heads cast from life, slathered in gray paint and mounted on pedestals. One head is Mr. Richter's; the other, of his fellow German painter Blinky Palermo. Facing each other with closed eyes, in a gallery that is empty but for a small study version in a shadow box on the wall, the faux classical sculptures create an ambience of dry existential ennui (Johnson).

Other Galleries

CARSTEN HOLLER, ''KARSTEN HOLLER,'' Casey Kaplan, 416 West 14th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 645-7335, through June 19. Mr. Holler, a Stockholm-based Belgian who has exhibited extensively in Europe, likes to create disorienting interactive installations that are supposed to throw viewers into states of existential doubt. The main attraction here is a fun-house-like environment of revolving mirrored doors, a kind of walk-in kaleidoscope. Also, there is a set of blurry photographs shot in the woods of a species of mushroom that is visually beautiful but poisonous (Johnson).

''THE CAVE AND THE ISLAND,'' White Columns, 320 West 13th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 924-4212, through June 20. Organized by Xandra Eden, assistant curator for the Power Plant, a gallery in Toronto, this group show presents works loosely about nature by eight Canadians. Highlights include Jennifer Murphy's images of animals, rain and a skull made of sequins, reflective plastics, velvet and lace; Karen Azoulay's waterfall made of yarn and pompoms; David Armstrong Six's social-surrealist fantasies finely painted in gouache; Damian Moppett's video of a bearded man in 19th-century clothing wandering around in a rain forest; and a video by the soundmaking team GLN that might be a spoof of New Age music (Johnson).

JONATHAN MEESE, ''DR. NO'S SON,'' Leo Koenig, 249 Centre Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 334-9255, through June 8. Working with hectic, seemingly demented urgency to keep German Expressionist traditions alive, this young, Berlin-based artist makes bracingly hideous, scatalogically colored paintings about indecipherable mythological themes featuring monstrous military leaders. A pair of bronze sculptures look like melted heads from a wax museum (Johnson).

* ''ROCK'S ROLE (AFTER RYOANJI),'' Art in General, 79 Walker Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-0473, through June 26. This serenely beautiful exhibition, part of the New Sound, New York sound art festival and the Buddhism Project Consortium, explores the influence of John Cage's notion that music could be the aural equivalent of a Japanese garden's rocks and sand. The works of 17 composers and artists flow from 15 speakers in a gardenlike installation (seating provided), creating a sonic collage while maintaining a remarkable degree of individuality. A memorable lesson in sound, space, listening and the history of avant-garde music (Smith).

''WORLDSCAPES: THE ART OF ERRO,'' Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780, through July 17. The career of Erro, a prodigiously productive Pop-style painter said to be Iceland's most acclaimed artist, is featured in a nearly 50-year retrospective at the Grey Art Gallery. It will not persuade you that he is a great painter, but you may be taken by his manic graphic activity, antic humor and promiscuous sampling from popular culture. If so, you may also want to see ''Femmes Fatales'' at the Goethe Institut, 1014 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 439-8700, through July 17, which offers 10 colorful paintings from an Erro series devoted to female comic book superheroes (Johnson).

Last Chance

''ARCADIA AND METROPOLIS: MASTERWORKS OF GERMAN EXPRESSIONISM FROM THE NATIONALGALERIE BERLIN,'' Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200, through Monday. In 1937 the Nazis seized a large collection of Expressionist works from the Kronprinzen Palace in Berlin, Germany's first museum of contemporary art. But this branch of Nationalgalerie Berlin has made great strides in restoring what was the heart of its collection. This show of 40 works by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Karl Schmidt-Rottluff, Emil Nolde, Max Beckmann, George Grosz, Otto Dix, Hannah Hoch, Paula Modersohn-Becker and others touches on the history of German modern art -- Expressionism, Dadaism, Neue Sachlichkeit -- from around 1910 through the post-World War I period. Its title is drawn from the early preference of the Expressionists for rural places versus their later attraction to the city. Satirical thrusts at the failures of the Weimar Republic by Hoch, Dix and Grosz are also standouts. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+ (Glueck).

* RED GROOMS, ''New Works in Wood,'' Marlborough, 40 West 57th Street, (212) 541-4900, through tomorrow. One of the artist's best shows in years concentrates almost exclusively on small reliefs made of constructed, painted and somewhat whittled wood. His familiar cast of New York people and places are once more tenderly caricatured, but with renewed vitality and economy (Smith).

* JEFF KOONS, ''Highlights of 25 Years,'' C&M Arts, 45 East 78th Street, (212) 861-0020, through tomorrow. This excellent 27-piece survey touches on all phases of Mr. Koons's career, including greatest hits like the basketballs mysteriously hovering in aquarium tanks; the Mylar ''Rabbit'' balloon cast in shiny stainless steel; and the sexy blonde embracing the Pink Panther in glazed ceramic. The climax of the show is the 10-foot-tall ''Balloon Dog.'' Made of stainless steel and coated in coppery translucent orange, it is a breathtaking symbol of the inflationary euphoria and anxiety of our times (Johnson).

JIM RICHARD, ''Decor,'' Oliver Kamm 5BE Gallery, 504 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-0979, through tomorrow. Mr. Richard, who is based in New Orleans and has been exhibiting his work since the mid-1970's, makes suavely satiric paintings of over-decorated rooms in the homes of art collectors. He simplifies and abstracts his photographic sources into cartoonish, Pop-style pictures marked by satiny smooth surfaces, muted colors, smoldering light and Cubist complication (Johnson).

* ''ROTH TIME: A DIETER ROTH RETROSPECTIVE,'' Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400, and P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, (718) 784-2084, through Monday. This exhaustive, exhausting but ultimately astounding exhibition offers total immersion in the art of the German-born, Swiss-based multimedia dynamo Dieter Roth (1930-1998), who not only erased the line between art and life, but also fused them into a single insoluble entity. With nearly 400 works of painting, drawing, prints, sculpture, assemblage, collage, music, poetry, film, photography, video and sound, and using every imaginable kind of found object or material -- foodstuffs included -- the exhibition moves through 50 years of incessant, obsessive art-making with remarkable clarity. It culminates in a presentation of five enormous installation pieces at the Modern's little-sister institution, P.S. 1, that reveal a seemingly boundless universe of artistic activity and a radically new picture of an artist at work. MoMA Queens hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays to 7:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+. P.S. 1: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 6 p.m.; $5; students and 62+, $2 (Smith).

FRANK STELLA, ''Exotic Birds,'' Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 744-2313, through tomorrow. Looking at Mr. Stella's three big, splashily painted reliefs from a 1976 series, it is easy to forget how shockingly flamboyant they seemed in their day. Now, with their curvy, tilting forms cut from honeycomb-core aluminum panels and neatly puzzled together within wide slanting frames, they seem prettily demure compared to what has happened since in painting as well as in sculpture (Johnson).
