HEADLINE: Over the Rainbow, a Melting Pot

BYLINE: By KEVIN CAHILLANE

DATELINE: Mountain Lakes 

 BODY:
WHEN the train station was erected in Mountain Lakes almost a century ago, the borough's leaders left a message in stone for future dwellers:
 ''That the Mountain Lakes which you shall know, shall have fulfilled the splendid promise of the Mountain Lakes of 1912; that Mountain Lakes in the maturity of her charms shall give to you the pleasure and the joy she has given us in her youth.''
 If any place in New Jersey has retained a sense of timelessness, it is surely Mountain Lakes, a picture postcard town of about 4,300 tucked into the rolling hills between Interstates 80 and 287 in Morris County. It is a 2.7-square-mile patch where residents still swim the man-made lakes, walk the tree-lined boulevard and live in the original two- and three-story stucco homes much as they did when Woodrow Wilson was president. 
 It is not merely the physical landscape, though, that gives Mountain Lakes its enduring character. It is also a place where the high school has an honor code, the mayor leaves his door unlocked and families still supper at the Mountain Lakes Club. 
 ''It's a community that seems to have stood still in time and values,'' said Dr. John Kazmark, the school superintendent, who left Princeton for Mountain Lakes three years ago. ''It's a wonderful thing.''
 To outsiders, however, the wonder comes with a caveat. Mountain Lakes has also remained one of the more racially segregated communities in the state, with only 16 African-Americans living in the borough, according to the 2000 census. Though 14 percent of the state and nearly 3 percent of the county is black, African-Americans account for less than half of 1 percent of all residents in Mountain Lakes. What's more, the town does not quite roll out the red carpet for new residents -- the million-dollar houses change hands infrequently, and the borough, like a handful of others in the state, does not allow ''For Sale'' signs. 
 But Mountain Lakes is far from the only community that is so uniform, according to a Harvard study released last year. And as statistically insignificant as 16 black residents may seem, it is still 16 more than in 1990, when no blacks lived in the borough. 
 ''It's a difficult issue,'' said Jud Breslin, the former three-term mayor and current councilman who has raised five boys in town with his wife, Wendy. ''We're always looking to increase our diversity. We have to make an effort to get our kids to understand that the world outside Mountain Lakes looks different than the one inside. And in terms of nationality and religion, we're the most diverse we've ever been.'' 
 He is right. Whites now make up just 93 percent of the total population of the borough as compared with about 97.4 percent a decade ago. Mountain Lakes, to be sure, is not the only predominately white town in Morris County, one of the 10 wealthiest counties in the country. It is, however, one with a famously exclusionary reputation. 
 In Dr. Rita Heller's 1998 documentary ''Chanceman's Brothers and Sisters: The Origins of the 20th Century Morris County Black Community,'' Gwendolyn Boyce, who was the daughter of live-in domestics in Mountain Lakes in the 1930's, offered this recollection of life there: ''When I lived in Mountain Lakes, I don't know if it was written but everyone seemed to know that there were no blacks to live there, no Jews to live there, no Catholics to live there. It was a very closed, restricted community.''
 Dr. Heller, an associate professor of history at the County College of Morris, believes that Mountain Lakes was hardly an exception in its degree of segregation. ''Residential diversity is of a very recent vintage in WASP America,'' she said.
 George Wilson, 77, remembers going to school with the black children of servants in Mountain Lakes. Mr. Wilson, who was born and raised in Mountain Lakes but is perhaps best remembered for coaching the high school basketball team to two state titles, says he realized the town was unusual only after he left for several years to play professional baseball.
 ''It wasn't ever discussed,'' he said about the town's uniformity. ''We thought that was the way it was across the world. If something didn't happen in Boonton or Mountain Lakes, you just didn't know about it. It was our own little Shangri-La.'' 
 Mr. Wilson, who now lives in Boonton Township, says the only color that matters in Mountain Lakes today is green. ''Maybe I'm naive, but I think that anyone can live in Mountain Lakes that can afford to live in Mountain Lakes,'' he said. 
 Cost is certainly a factor. Buying a house in Mountain Lakes is not for the faint of pocketbook. The average home in the borough sold for about $800,000 the past year, according to Cindy Grebenstein, a long-time Mountain Lakes real estate agent. There are now 34 houses on the market, and 18 of them dangle a price tag north of $1 million. There is little chance that more housing will be added. More than two decades ago, the state public advocate sued the town and others for exclusionary zoning and failing to provide opportunity for low-income housing, but dropped the case before trial. 
 Price alone does not account for the dearth of diversity. Boonton Township, which sends its children to Mountain Lakes High School, shares a similar socioeconomic backdrop yet has more than three times as many blacks as Mountain Lakes. 
 There is also something of a wild card in the Mountain Lakes real estate market. Because of a ''gentleman's agreement'' between the borough council and local real estate agents, no ''For Sale'' signs are permitted on the ample lawns. (Local officials say this is for aesthetic reasons, but contractors are not held to the same standard, and landscaping, painting and building signs are on conspicuous display.) Many houses, in fact, never even hit the open market.
 While deep pockets may be all that is required to secure a mortgage, it may not ensure a welcome Wagoneer for people of color, says Loreine Ghani. The daughter of Egyptian parents, Ms. Ghani, 34, lived in Mountain Lakes twice before graduating from its high school in 1988. Though she loved the natural beauty and safe haven of the town, she objected to what she calls the ''parochial attitude regarding race and ethnicity.'' She said she endured racial slurs in grammar school and awoke one morning to find an unkind epithet on the garage door.
 Why did the Ghanis choose Mountain Lakes with eyes wide open? ''My parents cared about the reputation of the school system,'' Ms. Ghani said. 
 While Wildwood Elementary School and Briarcliff Middle School are held in high esteem, it is the high school that seduces. Last year, the average combined College Board score was a combined 1174, compared with the state average of 1018, with 97 percent of the graduating class attending college. 
 Yet the high school is experiencing its own brand of turmoil. In May 2001, Mountain Lakes filed a petition with the education commissioner to sever its relationship with Boonton Township, whose students account for almost 40 percent of the student body, citing concern over the school's growing size. Boonton Township filed a counter motion, and for now, state officials have ordered the two boards and their lawyers to resolve the dispute themselves. 
 Though the two towns are virtual mirror images of each other, Boonton Township does seem to offer the high school an added dollop of diversity. 
 ''I really like having Boonton Township kids,'' said Katie Chambers, a senior bound for Middlebury College in the fall. ''It brings people from all different backgrounds and makes the high school better.''
 Perhaps after all these years, Mountain Lakes is better described as set in its ways than somehow rooted in the past. With a median household income of about $140,000 a year and the accessories that accompany such good fortune, Mountain Lakes residents are not churning their own butter. Either by inertia or design, the borough remains exclusive, if only economically.
 Peter Holmberg, 36, a marketing executive and avid marathon runner, is not an atypical Laker. He was raised in Mountain Lakes, saw Kathleen Davis across a crowded school cafeteria and imagined a life beyond the small town together. Four children later, they live in the Village area near the storefronts and offices that comprise ''downtown.'' Though he feels a certain challenge raising children amid an idyllic backdrop of wealth and consumption, he is also surprised and delighted to be living among family, in-laws, friends and the children of his childhood friends. He likens it to a great song that never gets old.
 ''There are meaningful connections here,'' he said. ''I love and appreciate Mountain Lakes for what it is and what it is not.''

HEADLINE: New Jersey Public TV, Small but Ambitious

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
IN New York, the newscasts offered by the network affiliates were all about Friday night traffic snarls and local homicides of various sorts. About 100 miles to the south, in Philadelphia, the stations warned about an impending cicada infestation and seemingly ubiquitous fires and murders. It was sweeps month, when television stations vie for top ratings and the phrase, ''If it bleeds, it leads,'' is carved on the inside of every anchor's forehead.
 Yet on the New Jersey Network news that night, which reaches more than 100,000 households, the top story was a three-minute update on the uproar surrounding the proposed legislation to limit development in the Highlands. And on this Friday night in May -- a week before the Memorial Day weekend -- there was a long segment on ocean safety. While there was, indeed, a report on the murder trial of Jayson Williams, it did not include the histrionics and near-shouting that the reporters on the other networks felt obliged to resort to.
 ''With commercial TV going in the direction it has been going -- pretty earnestly, particularly at the local level -- it makes us easier to distinguish from the crowd,'' said William Jobes, NJN's director of news and public affairs. ''What you see there is traffic, weather and overnight crime. That is the field they have chosen to play on. We have chosen to play on an issues-centric journalism.'' 
 The news operation is the centerpiece of New Jersey Network -- the public television network whose reach spans the entire state -- praised by many and even grudgingly tolerated by critics who say coverage tends to be dull and leans toward the political. With 30 full-time staff members dedicated to gathering news, NJN says it has the largest such operation of any public television station in the country. 
 ''You could consider us the only full-service statewide news operation on public television,'' Mr. Jobes said. ''Other states have newsmagazines, so you could count them, but ours is the only regularly scheduled nightly newscast.''
 Yet even as distinguishable and distinguished as it is, the question is whether this is enough on which to base a network with an annual budget of $17.6 million -- rather small when compared with that of WHYY in Philadelphia, which is $27 million, or WNET in New York, whose budget is a whopping $180 million. In the increasingly crowded broadcast and cable television landscape, is a statewide public network necessary for New Jersey? With highly competent, and larger public broadcasting services in New York and Philadelphia reaching into all corners of the state, and quality documentaries showing up on many cable networks, does the blueprint designed for New Jersey Network three decades ago matter anymore?
 ''There is certainly more competition for all eyes,'' Gabriella Morris, board chairwoman of NJN and president of the Prudential Foundation in Newark, said in a recent interview. ''There are more things on the air. And people are more distracted and harder to reach than ever. But we strongly believe in public television. And in New Jersey in particular, it is a voice we don't have in the major markets that surround us. It gives us a connection to the community that mainstream TV just doesn't have.''
 New Jersey Network went on the air on April 5, 1971, three years after the State Legislature established the New Jersey Public Broadcasting Authority and voters approved a $7.5 million bond to build broadcast facilities and transmission towers around the state. (Though WNET, New York City's public television station, was technically licensed to operate in Newark and include some coverage of New Jersey when it was established in 1961, it has long broadcast primarily out of Manhattan -- though as a sop to the Garden State it reruns NJN's half-hour newscast at 5:30 every night.)
 Year after year, NJN would go to the State Legislature with hat in hand, begging for money to keep operating. Television -- even on a public level with moderate salaries -- is expensive to produce, and in the late 1980's and early 90's the state was contributing two-thirds of the network's budget. But then a recession came, along with persistent tax challenges by voters and precipitously declining ratings prompted by a boom in cable TV, leading some legislators to mutter about dropping the state subsidy for the network.
 With that scare, NJN executives and legislators got together and created the NJN Foundation for Public Broadcasting, which now raises as much as $8 million a year from individuals and foundations, to supplement the $7 million state subsidy as well as other revenue from subscriptions, donations and the sale of promotional items.
 ''We would like to move it as much as we can toward not needing state support,'' said State Senator Diane Allen, a Republican from Burlington County. ''In many respects, it would free the network, and we want to see it flourish.''
 Senator Allen has an unusual perspective on such things. As a young television reporter, she worked for NJN in the 1970's. Today Ms. Allen, a long-time legislator, is one of the network's more energetic advocates, both for its newscasts and other programming.
 ''My sense was in the beginning, it was more of a routine public broadcasting station, with less of a state orientation,'' she said. ''Having said that, it is doing a better job now, and doing it for the people of a state that has no other real broadcast outlet.
 ''It is fortunate for people in the state, when other broadcast stations have cut back so much on political news, that NJN exists,'' she continued. ''And it still does its service by having other state programming and its educational shows and all of the children's shows you expect from a public broadcasting station.''
 Still, even its signature program -- the evening newscast -- gets relatively scrawny ratings numbers. The average daily viewership of ''NJN News'' is about 107,000 of the state's three million households. By comparison, the newscasts of network affiliates in Philadelphia get about three times that many, and the New York affiliates attract five times as many viewers. 
 Still, legislative support for NJN is robust today; some lawmakers go so far as to say that the network's presence is vital to the state. Even critics concede that it provides the one televised newscast they can appear on and reach every voter in the state. And as any candidate for statewide office can attest to, that free exposure is invaluable. 
 ''From my perspective, I see a great deal more coverage of the governor than I'd like,'' said the Senate minority leader, Leonard Lance, a Democrat from Flemington.
 Yet even Mr. Lance, a harsh critic of Governor McGreevey who is himself contemplating a gubernatorial challenge, was quick to add: ''But Trenton is probably the last state capitol whose coverage is dominated by the print media. Even in Des Moines, the network affiliates dominate. To the extent that it offers an alternative, I want to see NJN thrive here.''
 And since the network has been making strides toward obtaining more and more of its own financing through the NJN Foundation, Senator Allen said, it has been enjoying greater bipartisan support.
 ''I know of no move to eliminate it, no one who doesn't support its goals,'' she said. ''They have capable leadership, and I can't imagine anyone wanting to see the network go away.''
 Since June 1994, that leadership has been headed by Elizabeth Christopherson, the network's sixth executive director, who had been a vice president of Bloomfield College and chairwoman of the New Jersey State Council on the Arts.
 Ms. Christopherson -- a commanding presence who makes laser-like eye contact with people -- has been pushing the network into as many paths as possible, particularly as the technology has advanced.
 Indeed, NJN was one of the first public broadcast entities to convert to digital signals, giving the network the ability to appear on the Internet as well as the airwaves and allowing it to offer services in an effort to make it indispensable to New Jersey residents. 
 For instance, the program ''NJ Works'' offers online job help and training for those looking for employment in the state. And the network's four television transmitters and other digital equipment are being used by local, state and federal governments as part of the homeland-security warning system, linking law enforcement agencies. In addition, there are online and over-the-air educational offerings. As broadband becomes more popular in homes, the network says, it will offer multiple channels, much the way HBO does for cable subscribers.
 ''We have had a history in recent years of being involved in strategic planning for the future, and we view it as our mandate to offer as much as we can in the way of local and statewide services,'' said Ms. Christopherson, a 1971 Wellesley graduate who also serves on the national Public Broadcasting Service board.
 Many of the employees could earn more money at commercial broadcast outlets -- even Ms. Christopherson makes only $116,000 a year, which is a half to a third of what the heads of stations in major markets earn. Yet many seem to stay at NJN for a lifetime.
 Janice Selinger, a producer who has won several Emmy Awards since coming to NJN, left WCBS-TV 24 years ago. And the primary news anchor, Kent Manahan, has been in her chair since 1975. Michael Aron, a former editor of New Jersey Monthly magazine, joined the network in 1982 to report on politics and has since been the host of several newsmagazine shows. And John Wynne, a member of the camera crew, started working at NJN in 1980, when it was operating out of a ramshackle building on the outskirts of the city and a decade before it moved to modern quarters in downtown Trenton, where its huge rooftop satellite dishes compete with the gold State House dome for a place in the capital's modest skyline.
 ''Look, would I want bigger budgets and more money?'' Ms. Selinger said. ''I wouldn't lie, who wouldn't? But I've done work like 'The Race for Open Space' (a documentary about development in New Jersey) with Charlie Gibson as a narrator. It was great, in-depth work that few people do anymore, and I got to use network talent. Even with lesser money, we find the way to do this kind of thing. So people stay and, because of that, we know the landscape.''
 Harvey Fisher, now the editor of New Jersey Lawyer and Ms. Christopherson's predecessor at NJN, says the network does well with the money it has to work with.
 ''Look, it is really expensive to do local programming,'' Mr. Fisher said. ''You couldn't possibly fill your schedule with it, no matter what you would like to do. You will have duplication of some programs in New York and Philadelphia, but that is to be expected.''
 Because of NJN's slimmer budget and smaller viewership, the station often loses out to New York and Philadelphia when it comes to broadcasting the more popular public shows. Frequently, programs like ''Nova'' and ''BBC World News'' are shown first on WHYY in Philadelphia or WNET in New York. If there is one complaint about NJN as a service, it is the duplication of programming, something Ms. Christopherson at once acknowledged but largely dismissed as a function of public television all over the country.
 ''Public television is, in a sense, an alternative service,'' she said. ''I see nothing wrong in something airing in Philadelphia at 8 p.m. and, if you miss it, getting to see it at 10 p.m. on NJN. The affiliates are good about working together like that. We aren't competitive when it comes to getting good programming on the air.''
 For his part, William Marrazzo, the president and chief executive of WHYY-TV and radio, Philadelphia's public broadcasting services, says he and Ms. Christopherson talk regularly about overlapping programming.
 ''Our mandates are the same, to do the best we can in localizing programming,'' Mr. Marrazzo said. ''On a good day, NJN might take the same 'Nova' we do at a different time and package it differently than we would based on a unique relationship that it has in New Jersey that doesn't exist for us, say, in Reading. On a good day, we would both localize it through Web sites and off-air outreach activities that truly add additional value.''
 For example, Mr. Marrazzo has changed the reach of WHYY radio, wiping out almost all of its music programming and going mostly to news, interviews and literary performances. Each weekday morning, the station produces inserts for ''Morning Edition,'' the news program produced by National Public Radio, and a two-hour local interview show, ''Radio Times.'' In addition, the nationally syndicated program ''Fresh Air'' is produced at WHYY.
 Ms. Christopherson says she has set a similar goal for NJN radio, which broadcasts on seven different FM frequencies around the state, from Sussex (88.5) in the north to Cape May Court House (90.3) in the south. With the exception of ''NJN News,'' which is broadcast on television, and infrequent hourlong arts and business shows, all of NJN radio consists of programming that is picked up from other public radio affiliates.
 ''We would love to have an hour news magazine or a talk show, something uniquely New Jersey,'' said Pharoah Cranston, the operations manager of NJN Radio, who oversees the small studio in Trenton. ''But until someone earmarks money for that, we will just have to keep the operation small.''
 The network is already doing that on television. NJN produces eight regular programs, including the Hispanic-oriented ''Images/Imagenes;'' ''On the Record'' with Mr. Aron, a favorite of political junkies around the state; and the Emmy-winning ''State of the Arts,'' a half-hour newsmagazine. All of those programs are underwritten largely by foundations and privates companies that cannot dictate how their donations will be spent. 
 For instance, the New Jersey State Council for the Arts and the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation finance ''State of the Arts,'' and Public Service Electric and Gas finances ''On the Record.''
 ''I would say that when we go to the community, people are not unwilling to commit to NJN,'' Ms. Christopherson said. ''If we continue to approach them correctly, we will keep our niche of providing local service for an incredibly rich and diverse state.''

HEADLINE: In Bankruptcy, but Avoiding Foreclosure

BYLINE: By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
FOUR years ago, Alfred and Elizabeth Metta of Brick were forced to file for personal bankruptcy to avoid foreclosure on the four-bedroom home they had bought for $147,000 in 1994.
 For five years they had fought vainly to keep up with their bills after Mr. Metta, a paramedic, was seriously injured on the job and needed rehab, and Mrs. Metta, a nurse, took maternity leave. They filed for Chapter 13 bankruptcy protection, which structured their debt into one big monthly payment, although it did not dissolve it. 
 ''We kept the house,'' Mrs. Metta said. ''That was the key to everything as it turns out.''
 While the Mettas struggled to keep to a court-ordered schedule of payments on their debt, something wonderful and unexpected happened: the value of their home began rising. In a pattern familiar to most people owning homes in New Jersey since the turn of the millennium, an ailing national economy brought the balm of lower interest rates, which helped to fuel home-buying frenzies in numerous communities. Because the demand for homes outstripped the number for sale, the value of virtually all houses rose sharply.
 When the Mettas had their home reappraised in 2001, they found its value had nearly doubled, and the most recent appraisal, in April, put the house's current value at $300,000.
 ''Real estate has really created new-found equity for people -- even the bankrupt,'' observed Brian Riccioni, the founder of the First Hallmark Mortgage Corporation of Somerville. Mr. Riccioni's mortgage company is one of several dozen in the region that provide ''subprime'' mortgage loans for people in positions like that of the Mettas.
 But First Hallmark is unusual in that 50 percent of its business involves such loans, and the company considers them its primary product. The Golden Mortgage Corporation of Bridgewater, by contrast, does about 10 percent of its business in subprime loans, said the chief executive, Ted Ark. ''They are extremely time-consuming,'' he noted, ''because of the complex paperwork.'' 
 Several mortgage companies mentioned that tough ''predatory lending'' statutes in New Jersey make it more difficult to operate in the state's subprime market. Since lenders face relatively high risk in offering subprime loans, they charge borrowers higher interest rates and fees.
 The national chain H & R Block makes subprime loans here, and Champion Mortgage, a division of Key Bank U.S.A., is a major player. Champion does not disclose what percentage of its business is made up of such loans, a spokesman said. 
 Mr. Riccioni set up First Hallmark five years ago while still in his 20's with the support of his father, who owned Sterling Mortgage of Somerville, a conventional mortgage company that has since dissolved.
 ''We set up a streamlined process specifically designed for people who have been in bankruptcy for a year, and who have shown they can make the payments on time,'' he said. 
 ''We can lend as much as 85 and sometimes 90 percent of the value of an owner's home in an effort to reorganize their debt, typically at 2 percent above the going conventional rate,'' Mr. Riccioni said. ''We have been using an adjustable rate loan option while rates have stayed low, in hopes of re-establishing credit so that if the new mortgage is paid on time, the borrower can come back to us after another year and we see if we can further improve the situation.''
 The Mettas had begun efforts to refinance with two other companies before being contacted by First Hallmark, and in each case, Mrs. Metta said, paid for an appraisal and spent a great deal of time gathering paperwork before the companies abruptly stopped answering their calls. 
 First Hallmark actively solicits the business of homeowners who have managed a year of timely payments under Chapter 13, said the company's president, Bruno Viscariello. ''In addition, we created a financial strategy for the borrower to plan for the future,'' he said. 
 For the Mettas, this was a productive approach. Last year, their brokers at First Hallmark -- which makes a profit by bundling a number of such loans and retailing them as investments -- refinanced their debts through an adjustable rate mortgage, with an interest rate fixed at 8.55 percent for the first two years. That cut the Mettas' payment under Chapter 13 by $1,000 a month.
 The brokers told them that if interest rates stayed low, home values kept rising and they kept making payments on time, their credit rating would repair itself and at some point they could refinance again at a conventional rate, the Mettas said.
 Last month, they did so, obtaining a 6.25 percent interest rate and borrowing enough additional money to add on a longed-for family room.
 Another borrower in Chapter 13 protection, Len Irvine of Belvedere, tells a similar story. His wife became disabled with multiple sclerosis as he was trying to open a business. Mr. Irvine created Infotel Communications to provide telecommunications systems to large companies, but then received only half what he had expected in Small Business Administration start-up funds. He quickly found himself facing the loss of his home, not to mention the business.
 After receiving a flier in the mail, he decided to use First Hallmark to refinance his debt. Mr. Irvine closed in mid-May on a $200,000 mortgage on his house -- built in 1983 for $110,000 and currently appraised at $300,000 -- with a 6.95 interest rate, providing him the operating capital he needed to double his business.
 There were 41,730 Chapter 13 personal bankruptcies in New Jersey last year, according to John Tylutki, the chief operating officer at First Hallmark, and 40,940 the year before. He said his firm closes 110 to 120 refinancing loans a month for homeowners in Chapter 13, and he expects business to grow.
 ''The subprime business is a growing business,'' agreed Melissa Cohn of the Manhattan Mortgage Company, which has an office in Freehold, ''because, for one thing, 'A' lenders are now using more restrictive credit guidelines. No-money-down mortgages are still available, but you must have good credit, be able to verify income and meet the bank's liquidity requirement,'' thereby showing that assets are available in an emergency.
 That has increased the flow of borrowers who do not fit the creditworthy profile but have nonetheless benefited from the strong appreciation of their homes and want the benefit of interest rates that, while rising slightly, are still near record lows, Ms. Cohn said.
 ''Frankly, I just don't understand all that stuff,'' Mrs. Metta confessed, but she added, ''What I get is that we are in a way, way better situation than we were three, two and even one year ago.''

HEADLINE: Environmentalists Wary Of Seattle Port's Growth

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW

DATELINE: Seattle 

 BODY:
AS the spring and summer cruise season gets under way, this increasingly cruise-friendly city is the port of call to a record number of large vessels, most of them bound for to Alaska. 
 The 50 percent increase in cruise traffic over the last year thrills Seattle port and tourism officials, but environmentalists are concerned about the effect of waste water and other pollutants from the ships on area waters and marine life. That worry was prompted in part by a major spill in May 2003: 16,000 gallons of sewage sludge from a Norwegian Cruise Line ship, on its first trip from here to Alaska, was dumped -- illegally, according to the state -- into the Strait of Juan de Fuca, near the entrance to Puget Sound, an already environmentally troubled body of water. 
 An estimated 150 ships carrying about 276,000 passengers will call at Seattle from May-to-September, according to Seattle's Convention and Visitors Bureau, up from 99 last year. Only six large cruise ships left for Alaska from Seattle's port in 1999. 
 Several major cruise lines -- Holland America and Princess among them -- have added a second cruise ship this year to make the trip from Seattle to Alaska; the average large cruise ship carries between 3,000 and 5,000 passengers and crew. Seattle has responded by expanding its cruise capacity at the waterfront: In 2000, the Port of Seattle, the public corporation that operates transportation facilities in the area, opened the Bell Street Cruise Terminal at Pier 66 and last year completed a $16 million two-berth facility at Terminal 30. 
 Passengers are enthusiastically embracing the convenience and affordability of setting out from Seattle instead of Vancouver, British Columbia, where most Alaska cruises had embarked until a few years ago. 
 There are relatively few inexpensive direct flights from the eastern United States to Vancouver; as a result, many passengers bound for Alaska had to take ferries or connecting flights to Vancouver. And with the increased speed of the newer cruise ships, the trip from Seattle now takes no longer than it once did from Vancouver, which is over 100 miles closer to Alaskan waters. 
 The cruise business is bringing much-needed money to the Seattle area. While the port has spent more than $50 million to expand its capacity, according to a recent economic study by the Port of Seattle, cruise ships calling at Seattle last year brought $124 million in business revenue, $39 million in payroll and $3.8 million in taxes into the regional economy in 2003. The revenues are expected to increase by 50 percent in 2004, the agency said. 
 After last year's sewage spill by the Norwegian Sun, which the cruise line said was accidental, the Washington State Department of Ecology negotiated a memorandum of understanding with the Port of Seattle and the North West Cruiseship Association, which represents major cruise lines that dock in Seattle. The accord, signed in April, requires that all ships be equipped with advanced sewage treatment systems certified by the Coast Guard before waste water can be discharged into Washington state waters. 
 With those systems in place and the required certification ships can release waste water at speeds of six knots or more and when at least one mile from berth at the Port of Seattle. 
 Discharges of sludge, which unlike waste water contains solid material, are permitted 12 nautical miles or more from shore, but discharges of untreated waste water and sewage treated by older methods can occur only outside state waters.
 State environmental officials said that the agreement would prevent sewage spills like the one last year from the Norwegian liner and that the accord goes much further than current federal maritime law, which allows ships to release conventionally treated waste water anywhere and untreated sludge within three nautical miles from shore. 
 ''The cruise industry has accepted a very high set of treatment standards and reporting standards for their vessels,'' said Larry Altose, an ecology department spokesman. 
 But environmentalists say that the state and the cruise industry have fallen far short of what is necessary to protect Washington state waters and marine life, especially in light of probable increases in cruise ship traffic, and they are leery of a voluntary memorandum of understanding. They say that the state should enact a stringent law with real enforcement teeth. One attempt at passing such a law failed earlier this year in the state legislature. 
 ''The state has taken the cruise industry's word,'' said Fred Felleman, northwest director of Ocean Advocates, a maritime environmental group. ''I think we are setting ourselves up for a bad mistake. ''
 Referring to the memorandum of understanding, Mr. Felleman also asked, ''What's the likelihood that they are going to comply? My confidence is next to zero given their international and local track record.''
 But John Hansen, president of the North West Cruiseship Association, which is based in Vancouver, insisted that the cruise lines would comply with the accord and that ''we are happy to have it.''
 He added that most of the waste-water treatment equipment on ships is far better than shore-based facilities. ''For the most part, they are well beyond the standards required,'' he said.

HEADLINE: It's 3 Blocks From Fifth Avenue, But It's Just Like Fifth Avenue

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
THE rich limestone facade at 131-135 East 66th Street, built in 1906 at the northeast corner of Lexington, exudes the confidence of Fifth Avenue apartment houses built for bankers, brokers and lawyers.
 Inside, the early tenants decorated sumptuously -- photographs of one apartment, lived in by the building's architect, Charles A. Platt, reveal couches in tufted velvet, silk wall hangings lining the upper walls, and a beamed ceiling painted in Renaissance style.
 Some idea of the scale of entertaining can be found in a New York Times account of a party in December 1933. Guests at a ''circus party'' arrived as acrobats, animal tamers, trapeze artists and sword swallowers. The apartment was done in circus decor, with a large tent covering its double-height studio space. 
 That month, one tenant, John Woolsey, a federal judge, made his historic decision that James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' was not obscene and could be brought into the United States. Judge Woolsey noted that, regarding the book's many sexual references, ''it must always be remembered that his locale was Celtic and his season spring.'' 
 The building's roots can be traced to just after 1900, when a group of artists began construction on the famous ''studio block'' of West 67th Street just off Central Park West, putting up high-rise structures that combined studios and dwelling spaces. The new buildings were successful beyond the artists' expectations, and in 1905 a syndicate that included the painter Walter Russell, one of the West 67th Street veterans, began work on an East Side version closer to the moneyed class.
 For the site at the northeast corner of 66th and Lexington, Russell's group at first planned a building of light brick. It retained the architects Pollard & Steinam and B. Hustace Simonson, who had worked on many of the West 67th Street studios. Those names appear on the East 66th Street building application. 
 But when the completed building's design was published in many architectural journals in 1908, Platt was the only architect associated with it. Born in 1861 to a patrician, cultured family, Platt studied art in Paris and by the 1890's began designing for neighbors in the summer colony of Cornish, N.H. -- at first gardens, and soon whole houses. 
 Platt had published a book, ''Italian Gardens,'' in 1894. In 1907, he designed the double house built by Sara Delano Roosevelt for herself and her newlywed son and daughter-in-law, Franklin and Eleanor, at 47-49 East 65th Street. 
 Perhaps Platt was brought in by the real estate investor Frederick Culver, who came late to the project; Platt had already designed a house for Culver's wife, Anna. Or perhaps Platt was in on the project at the beginning, but was not considered a ''real'' architect. Either way, he produced a ''real'' building, with a chaste, authoritative English renaissance-style limestone facade, sumptuous in its cool reserve. It was a sharp contrast with the typical New York apartment house encrusted with assembly-line ornament. The new 131-135 East 66th Street was like Le Cirque compared with Nedick's. 
 Writing in The Architectural Record in 1908, the critic Arthur C. David said that ''out of the thousands of apartment houses which have been erected in New York during the past 30 years, probably less than 25 have been designed by really competent architects'' -- and Platt's building was definitely one of these. David praised Platt particularly for eschewing the showy marble lobbies favored by speculative buildings and instead employing a ''strictly economical propriety of treatment.'' 
 Although the architects who filed the plans did not get official credit, they had some influence on the design. The apartment layouts repeat almost exactly the double-height studio plan used on West 67th Street, with single-height rooms on the south face connected to double-height ''studios'' on the north. The north-facing studio windows, many with leaded glass, are visible from the rear courtyard, which is usually left unlocked during the day and is accessible from Lexington Avenue.
 The building was built as a partial co-op, with some units held for rental. Sale prices are not known, but an early advertisement offered some of the 9-to-11-room duplexes at rents of $300 to $350 a month. David described the studio spaces as ''positively exhilarating.'' The building has a nominal twin at 130 East 67th Street, built a year afterward; the architects listed on the building permit are Rossiter & Wright.
 The 1910 census indicates that not all artists led lives of penury. Platt, 48, is listed with his wife, Eleanor, four children and four servants. A portrait painter, Florence Thaw, 46, had three servants: butler, waitress and seamstress. Another tenant was Howard Russell Butler, 54, who gave up his law practice in the 1880's to study under the artist Frederic Church, ran Carnegie Hall and supervised the construction of Andrew Carnegie's mansion at 91st and Fifth, now the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. 
 Today, the building is as discreet as ever. The co-op has resisted the temptation to cut storefronts into the Lexington Avenue frontage, chop out the facade for air-conditioners or rip out the original wooden windows. 
 James Torrey, the co-op's president, says that it is about to embark on a multiyear renovation program, starting with the roof and including the parapets, windows and limestone facade, which is soiled and lusterless. The great two-story columns at the entrance are in their natural state, and offer an idea of the facade's potential majesty.
 But the projecting metal cornice will need substantial work, he says: ''It's become a pigeon hotel.''

Look For
Although the rear courtyard, usually accessible from Lexington Avenue in the daytime, is a typically barren space, look up to the huge, leaded glass windows lighting the double-height studio spaces. The building was designed by Charles A. Platt (photo).

BUILT -- 1906.

ADDRESS -- 131-135 East 66th Street, northeast corner of Lexington Avenue.

HOW TO GET THERE -- By subway, take the No. 6 train to Lexington and 68th. By bus, take the M101, M102 or M103, or the M66 crosstown, to Lexington and 68th, or the M1, M2, M3 or M4 to Madison and 68th.

HEADLINE: A Richer Mix of Stores For a Once-Rough Area

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
SOME neighborhoods, SoHo most notably, find that their mix of stores changes as wealthier residents replace old-timers and have more desire to buy designer clothes than 60-cent coffees.
 Something similar is happening in the Flatbush Avenue section of central Brooklyn, although the shift is still subtle and the residents are not moving out. Rather, as young people move to the neighborhood from Manhattan and from other parts of Brooklyn, and as the immigrants from the Caribbean who live in the area become more affluent, the stores are becoming more vibrant and more varied to meet their needs. 
 Timothy Guillen, for instance, said he used to sell mainly athletic shoes in his Stride Rite shoe store on Flatbush Avenue. Today, he displays mostly boys' and girls' dress shoes. ''We are more family oriented now because there is less crime,'' he said. 
 Not long ago, the street was a low-income shopping area with a number of boarded-up storefronts and merchants featuring products priced at less than a dollar. ''These guys didn't invest anything in their stores, and they would disappear in the middle of the night, owing the landlord several months rent,'' said Jack Katz, executive director of the Flatbush Avenue business improvement district.
 He said chain stores, including Lane Bryant, Radio Shack, Petland and Ashley Stewart, had moved in recent years into spaces formerly occupied by local retailers. 
 The growing economic strength of the neighborhood, which is bracketed by the Q subway line on one side and the 2 and 5 on the other, is not only encouraging local retailers to change their offerings, but also attracting national retailers. As a result, commercial rents are increasing, according to real estate executives.
 ''Eight years ago, I was involved in leasing some of these stores, and Flatbush Avenue had a 10 to 15 percent vacancy rate,'' said John G. J. Ritter, an executive vice president of Sholom & Zuckerbrot Realty, a brokerage firm active in Queens and Brooklyn. At that time, he said, ''rental rates were in the high teens'' in terms of dollars per square foot annually. ''Now,'' he added, ''the local rental rates match those of suburban malls, $30 to $40 a square foot.''
 It was those rising rents that persuaded Mr. Guillen, a native of the Dominican Republic, to acquire a building and move his store to its current location about four years ago after nearly a decade in the neighborhood. ''The rent was getting very high, so I moved here and bought the building,'' he said. ''Now I pay a mortgage, not rent.''
 Mr. Ritter, who recently brokered the sale of three retail properties in Flatbush totaling 30,000 square feet for $3.5 million, said the neighborhood is experiencing tremendous growth. 
 On Flatbush Avenue, a business improvement district on the stretch between Cortelyou Road and Parkside Avenue provides security, sanitation and promotion services, and changes are also evident on streets leading out of Flatbush Avenue. 
 Five blocks away, Nicholas Correra said he had been expanding the selection of wines in his liquor store facing the Newkirk Avenue subway station on the Q line. ''I'm selling a lot more good wine than in the past,'' he said. He said residents who commute to Manhattan are increasingly stopping by to buy a bottle of wine for dinner. 
 Mr. Correra's store is in Newkirk Plaza, which opened in 1913. The shopping center has recently been improved, with new ironwork fences replacing crumbling concrete walls and new light fixtures and poles for promotional banners.
 John Broderick, executive director of the Flatbush Development Corporation, an economic development agency, said the city-financed project involved ''$1 million in amenities and $2 million to $3 million in construction underneath.''
 Mr. Broderick said that making shopping areas like Newkirk Plaza and Cortelyou Road more attractive was important to attract the younger people who are moving into the neighborhood. 
 ''The people coming here from Manhattan and Williamsburg are in their 30's, and they are looking to buy,'' he said. He said that three-story Victorian houses in the area are priced in the $800,000 range and that condos in the six-story apartment buildings that house the majority of residents are rapidly appreciating in price.
 ''Stores in Flatbush are changing to tap into this new income,'' Mr. Broderick said. He said the Dunkin' Donuts chain recently invested $500,000 to refurbish a store in Newkirk Plaza. An old barbershop on Cortelyou Road is being converted into a white tablecloth restaurant, and a farmer's market now operates on Saturdays at the nearby Public School 139. ''It's like a community meeting on Saturdays,'' he said.
 But the gentrification has gone only so far. During the electrical blackout last summer, several stores on Flatbush Avenue were broken into and looted.
 Mr. Katz said that when the business improvement district began organizing in 1986, there was a 30 percent vacancy rate along Flatbush Avenue. Now, he said, there are only three vacancies among the 270 storefronts in the 11-block district.
 He said the densely populated area was a natural draw for national retail chains. He said these include Staples and Old Navy as well as fast food chains like McDonald's, Burger King and Kentucky Fried Chicken. A 40,000-square-foot Modell's sporting goods opened recently on Church Avenue.
 ''This was a roughhouse neighborhood when I came here seven years ago,'' said Sol Velelis, the manager of a Cookie's Department Store on Flatbush Avenue. ''We would get packs of kids who would take a lot of merchandise. But things have settled down since then.''

HEADLINE: Rising Inflation and Rising Stocks? Why Not?

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT. 
Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of CBS MarketWatch. E-mail: strategy @nytimes.com.

 BODY:
STOCK market investors have many things to worry about these days. But neither interest rates nor inflation should be at the top of their list.
 That may come as a surprise to those who have dumped stocks in anticipation of higher short-term rates. Few of those investors appear to question the widely held notion that stocks are less attractive when interest rates rise. 
 But this belief is a fallacy, says Clifford S. Asness, managing principal at AQR Capital Management, a money management firm in New York. ''Fretting over rising rates is not rational,'' Mr. Asness said, ''as they should not be a hindrance to rising stock prices.'' 
 Of course, if other things were equal, a climb in interest rates would be cause for concern, because the higher rates add to businesses' borrowing costs and can slow the pace of economic growth. 
 But the Federal Reserve's policy makers do not raise interest rates in a vacuum. They act when they believe that inflation is rising; in these circumstances, higher interest rates have only a small net effect on the average company.
 To understand why, it is helpful to recall that interest rates -- when the Fed is on its game -- tend to follow inflation up and down. People who believe that stocks are invariably worth less when interest rates are higher presumably also believe that companies cannot earn more when inflation is higher.
 Historically, though, the average company's earnings have grown faster when inflation is relatively high. In other words, the stock market is a good long-term hedge against inflation.
 Investors often miss this, because they tend to focus only on corporate earnings over the previous few years. Even at times when inflation is heading back up, for example, they expect earnings growth to continue at the slower pace that was established when inflation was low. In effect, they view stocks as a poor inflation hedge; when inflation worsens, they punish them accordingly.
 The failure to see stocks as a good inflation hedge is part of ''money illusion,'' which occurs when investors confuse nominal, or reported, prices with real, or inflation-adjusted, ones. The phrase traces back to a 1979 article by two finance professors, Franco Modigliani and Richard A. Cohn. (Professor Modigliani, then at M.I.T., was a Nobel laureate in economics in 1985; he died in 2003. Professor Cohn, then at the University of Illinois at Chicago, is now at the University of Hartford.)
 In the article, the professors argued that investors in the late 1970's, a time of double-digit inflation, were placing unreasonably low valuations on stocks by mistakenly assuming that a company's nominal earnings were the same as its real ones and thus would not grow faster with higher inflation. In effect, the professors forecast the great bull market of the 1980's and 90's.
 Their insight was based more on theoretical speculation than on historical analysis. But recent studies of market data and investor psychology have shown that they were right. One of the most comprehensive has been circulating in academic circles since April; it found strong evidence of money illusion over a long period -- June 1928 to December 2001. Its authors are the finance professors Randolph B. Cohen and Tuomo Vuolteenaho of Harvard and Christopher K. Polk of Northwestern. A copy is at http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3
 /papers.cfm?abstract-id=548402.
 Another good illustration of money illusion came in the late 1990's. Then, because inflation and interest rates had been low for several years, investors priced stocks too dearly. By early 2000, the average price-to-earnings multiple of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was above 20; in the late 1970's, it was below 8. The bear market of 2000 to 2002 can be viewed in part as the market's attempt to correct years of gross overvaluation.
 To be sure, some advisers, including Mr. Asness, say that the bear market accomplished only part of the job, and that stocks are still overvalued. So they don't plan to jump wholeheartedly into stocks anytime soon.
 Nevertheless, Mr. Asness says, worries about interest rates should not make you any less bullish today than you were six months ago.

HEADLINE: Adding Value To Immigrants' Cash

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER

 BODY:
ON the highway connecting El Salvador's national airport to the capital, San Salvador, most of the billboards don't promote luxury cars, fancy tourist hotels or clothing stores. Instead, they advertise the electronic transfer of remittances -- las remesas -- the money earned by Salvadoran men and women in the United States and sent back in allotments of maybe $200 or $300 a month.
 For hundreds of years, immigrant workers in America have sent modest amounts to their families in the old country, often by hand -- through a trusted friend or an informal agent. Entire villages in Poland and Greece survived off such homely remittances in the 1950's. 
 Next week, for the first time, heads of state of the world's wealthiest nations plan to discuss remittances, in a belated acknowledgment of their huge role in providing aid to the poor. 
 Those small bundles of money add up to one of the biggest transfers of wealth from rich countries to poor ones. The global remittance market may be as much as $150 billion annually, triple the development aid given by the wealthy nations to the poor and, in many countries, far more than direct foreign investment.
 When they meet on Tuesday at Sea Island, Ga., President Bush and the other leaders from the Group of 8 industrialized nations intend to discuss ways to reduce the cost of sending the money home, and to make it more useful for poor nations once it gets there. But the range of ideas on the table is fairly narrow: reducing the size of commissions paid to companies that transfer the money, drawing immigrants to the traditional bank and financial system so more of the money is saved and made available for loans, and using those savings for specific small-scale development programs.
 Absent is any discussion of the plight of the workers who earn and send back the money. They often risk their lives to reach a rich country like the United States, where they may hold down two jobs and earn less than $20,000 a year, suffer years of separation from their families and endure an uncertain legal status.
 Nor will the leaders examine why poorer societies continually need to export labor to survive -- or what can be done to break the cycle.
 Despite these limits, Manuel Orozco, Central America project director for the Inter-American Dialogue, a research group based in Washington, says the discussion at the summit meeting is an important step forward. ''It's a backdoor way to begin talking about migration and these workers, a subject that is very sensitive in rich nations,'' he said. ''On balance, it is positive to begin these discussions and understand the critical importance of remittances.''
 By their nature, such meetings tend toward a cosmic perspective; the lives of individual workers are often missing from discussions of trade and globalization. Government leaders dedicated to dismantling barriers to the free flow of goods and services often avoid talking about opening borders to the people who make those goods or perform those services.
 But the discovery over the last five years that remittances are a huge and essential money source for developing countries like Albania, El Salvador, Tonga and Lebanon is putting some aspects of labor on the global trade agenda. Mr. Orozco and the Inter-American Development Bank put together the first studies showing how remittances had exploded with globalization and the technological revolution that allowed money to be wired quickly to ever-more-remote areas of the developing world.
 Now the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are tracking the global flow of remittances. Dilip Ratha, a senior economist at the bank, prepared the charts and studies for the talks this week. ''If we can reduce the cost of sending these remittances, it would mean an additional $10 billion flowing to the poor in developing nations,'' Mr. Ratha said. ''If we can get the money moving through formal channels, that would mean greater savings and more credit for these people.''
 Kathleen Newland, director of the Migration Policy Institute, a group that studies immigration issues, said the discussion should include recommendations for allowing migrant workers to travel back and forth legally, so they could take an active role in improving their home communities. ''That would have a bigger impact on development,'' she said.
 Though remittances cover basic expenses for poor families, like food, clothing, shelter and some education, poor countries need more investment and entrepreneurship. With foreign aid at low levels and foreign investors preferring proven powerhouses like China, many poor nations increasingly depend on their own workers to go abroad and send money home.
 DEVELOPMENT experts like Dani Rodrik, professor of international political economy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, said they would be disappointed if world leaders failed to address the larger issues of the labor force. ''Return migration is crucial in the long run,'' he said. ''Workers returning home with their remittances could become a huge new flow for new investments as long as there were enough incentives to invest.''
 Though many workers return to their home country when economic opportunities are offered there, migration for the most part has been a one-way street. Workers come to the United States or other wealthy nations and, often, their families eventually follow. Some critics fear that there will be a permanent class of countries that survive by providing cheap labor to rich nations.
 ''With this now-highly mobile labor force going to countries with the jobs, you could see perpetually underdeveloped societies that will always need to export their labor to survive,'' said Joseph Siegle, a fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. ''I don't think that's the long-term solution we are looking for.''

HEADLINE: Going Farther Afield to Develop Homes

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

DATELINE: TORRINGTON 

 BODY:
ONE of the most adventurous of major developers seeking Connecticut property outside of famously overpriced Fairfield County is the Baker Companies of Pleasantville, N.Y. It is simultaneously building single-family subdivisions in Torrington, Canton, Wallingford and Middlebury and a town-house complex in Danbury, for a total of 442 units in four counties.
 Norman C. Greenberg, vice president of the company, said: ''We are recognizing that people are looking to move into areas that heretofore have not been in as much demand -- too far out. But people are commuting greater distances because of pricing.'' 
 Developers are also recognizing what Barry Rosa, vice president of Prudential Connecticut Realty, said ''is not just price.'' There is also the matter of finding attractive land in Fairfield County large enough to do a subdivision of 70 or 80 homes. 
 But move to Torrington? This faded, former industrial city, an aberration among Litchfield County's country-chic towns and villages? Many potential home buyers automatically respond by saying, ''No thanks!''
 ''That's something people have to get over,'' said Joanne Carroll, publisher of Connecticut Builder Magazine and former president of the Connecticut Homebuilders' Association. ''It isn't the grungy manufacturing town it used to be. People are moving there first for affordability. Then they find out how pretty it is -- the countryside is really beautiful with mountains and lakes.''
 Moreover, Torrington is in the throes of redevelopment, with a Home Depot, BJ's Wholesale Club, Wal-Mart and new downtown boutiques and offices.
 There is also Sharon Dante's ballet company, called Nutmeg Conservatory for the Arts, and the Warner Theater on Main Street. Built by Warner Brothers in 1931 as an ornate showcase for its movies, it has been restored as a legitimate theater with $10 million of state and private money. It recently converted a property across the street as a satellite theater for more intimate productions.
 Torrington is also getting a $47 million state courthouse, which should enhance the downtown economy, said Martin J. Connor, the city planner. 
 At Pleasantview, the Baker Companies' Torrington subdivision on Torringford Street (Route 183), the last group of a total of 122 homes is under construction on lots of a half acre and larger. Of the 70 percent that have been sold, most were contracted before the bulldozer hit the dirt. 
 More than a third of the 163-acre tract is wooded green space, and the development is bordered by a nature preserve where deer, small animals, birds and wild turkey roam against a backdrop of green mountains. 
 Covering 1,953 square feet to 2,798 square feet and priced from $264,060 to $324,840, the homes have three or four bedrooms, two-and-a-half bathrooms, two-story foyers, family great rooms, living rooms, separate dining rooms, dens, large kitchens with pantries, breakfast areas and center island work stations, master suites, decks and two-car garages. Any of the seven models would cost from the mid-$500,000's to the high $600,000's in Westchester or Fairfield, Mr. Greenberg said.
 But people now living and working in New Britain, Bristol and other towns in the greater Hartford area are the prevalent buyers, said Sandy Banks, a sales agent. 
 Judy and Walter Curry have lived at Pleasantview for 18 months. He is the head track and field coach at Wesleyan University in Middletown, and she works in the graduate liberal studies program. ''We used to travel for an hour and 15 minutes from our home in Massachusetts to jobs in Boston,'' Ms. Curry said. ''Now it only takes us 50 minutes from Torrington to Middletown.''
 After previously putting a $1,000 deposit on a house in Ellington, they discovered that a premium lot could increase the $350,000 price by up to $15,000. ''We went on the Internet,'' Ms. Curry said, ''and as soon as we visited Pleasantview and saw the perfect house for us, that was it.'' The lot premium was far less on their acre of land, and they are putting in a pool. ''We love it here,'' Ms. Curry said. ''It's an up-and-coming area.''
 Low home prices take some of the sting out of Torrington's property taxes, which are regarded as relatively high.
 Pleasantview is the least expensive of the Baker projects in Connecticut. Collins Crossing in Canton is the most expensive, based on the cost of land, the community's upscale character and the overall size of the homes. Otherwise, the layouts and finishes are similar to those in the other Baker developments. Five home styles of 2,850 square feet to 3,600 square feet are priced at $499,900 to $539,900. Seven homes are available out of a total of 71. 
 ''Canton is in the very active Hartford marketplace and has been developing quickly because homes there are less than in surrounding towns like Avon and Farmington,'' said Mr. Rosa of Prudential. ''But land prices have accelerated faster than home prices, and the cost of building materials -- from framing lumber to sheet metal -- has been skyrocketing, pushing home prices up.'' 
 At the two other Baker single-family-home subdivisions -- Brookside in Middlebury, with 126 homes, and Fieldstone Farm in Wallingford, with 95 homes, both in New Haven County -- the two sets of five models each are similar to one another. Some are in the Arts and Crafts style, with front porches and attractive stonework on pillars, foundations and around front doors.
 Brookside will begin sales next month on the next phase of homes; they will be 2,200 square feet to 3,200 square feet and priced at $365,000 to $450,000. Homes of 2,215 to 2,747 square feet at the Wallingford site are priced at $361,990 to $409,990.
 Common charges at Baker communities, covering services like lawn mowing and snow clearance, range from $101 a month in Wallingford to $216 a month at Lexington Court in Danbury, the only Fairfield County project among the five developments. At Lexington Court, 24 town houses in 12 buildings will circle a green. They will have entry foyers, large kitchens with breakfast rooms, master suites and two additional bedrooms, two-car garages and recreation rooms in the basement.

HEADLINE: They're Splendid, Except When They Fall

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER

DATELINE: GREENBURGH 

 BODY:
DARREL SEIFE felt as if he had lost an old friend. Out near the road, a V-shaped trunk was all that remained of the towering oak tree that had stood at the foot of his driveway since long before his arrival at the house 10 years ago. Where branches once arched high and shadows dappled on the pavement, a stump now sat awkwardly like a giant slingshot. 
 ''At first, it seemed like a good idea,'' Mr. Seife, still in mourning, said of the town officials who had told him they needed to take the tree down because it might not be stable. He could have accepted the responsibility for it and had it braced, but that would have made him liable had it fallen on someone. Still, the empty space in the yard loomed before him, a painful reminder. 
 ''It's not like losing a human life,'' he said, ''but I'm questioning whether I made the right decision.'' 
 If the town erred on the side of caution in the case of Mr. Seife's oak, it had good reason to do so. Last year it paid a $9 million out-of-court settlement to a Yonkers woman paralyzed and widowed when a tree fell onto her car on Central Park Avenue in 1998.
 Another lawsuit could well emerge from a similar accident this spring, in which a couple were killed as they were driving on the Saw Mill River Parkway in Hastings-on-Hudson. Their infant daughter, now 7 months old, was in a safety seat and survived.
 ''You can't play Russian roulette and just assume a tree isn't going to fall over in your municipality,'' said Paul J. Feiner, Greenburgh supervisor.
 Yet that is what some arborists say Westchester towns have been known to do: avoid inspecting trees because they fear advance knowledge could make them liable.
 ''They see it as a Catch-22,'' said Kevin Kenney, local manager in the Westchester office of Bartlett Tree Experts and an official for the New York State Arborists . ''If you inspect the trees you open yourself up for every liability possible. If you don't inspect them it's almost like you can plead ignorance.''
 On the tree issue, Mr. Kenney said, municipalities juggling tight budgets are often faced with a financial dilemma: They can spend their money either on large insurance policies to protect against lawsuits or on teams of arborists and town foresters conducting exhaustive examinations of trees. Finances are often tight for such tasks. 
 ''Budgets are getting cut and trees are always the first to go,'' said Michael H. Cook Jr., district manager for The Care of Trees Company in Westchester.
 Greenburgh, for one, has learned the high cost of neglect. Before the Central Park Avenue accident in 1998, the town did not have a thorough tree inspection program, said Cyrus M. Diamond, the lawyer representing Selamawit Hilliard, the Yonkers survivor. 
 ''While you can't inspect every tree in the town,'' Mr. Diamond said, ''certainly some locations are more important than others in my opinion, and trees that are adjacent to busy thoroughfares should be at the top of the list.''
 Since the settlement in the Hilliard case, Mr. Feiner said, Greenburgh has increased its liability insurance to $21 million from $4 million. In addition, it has about $100,000 in the budget for the removal of trees, with an arborist checking trees practically every day. About 100 trees have been removed in the last year, he said.
 As an added protection, technological advances allow arborists nowadays to gather highly specific information about tree health. Frank C. Buddingh, a Larchmont arborist, says one of the most commonly used devices is a digital microprobe that detects decay.
 ''If a tree is hollow,'' Mr. Buddingh said, ''I can tell you exactly to the millimeter how hollow.''
 But even with precautions like these, accidents happen. Robert A. Dennison III, regional director for the State Department of Transportation, said the tree that killed Stephen J. Spruck and Suzana Dedivanaj-Spruck on the Saw Mill in April was apparently not dead. Explaining that he and his co-workers take out about 5,500 dead or dying trees each year in the Hudson Valley, Mr. Dennison described the one that killed the Sprucks as a 50-year-old ash, in bud, that went down on a sunny day for no obvious reason.
 ''It's very sad and very unfortunate and frightening to us,'' he acknowledged, ''but we are looking every day and taking trees every day. We think what we're doing is a reasonable way to do this.''
 Mr. Kenney, the arborist, declined to comment specifically on the Saw Mill accident but noted: ''It's easy to be a Monday-morning quarterback. I drive down that road every day, and there are always tree crews doing work.''
 It only complicates the work of such crews that many people, like Mr. Seife mourning his oak in Greenburgh, are deeply ambivalent about losing trees.
 Mr. Dennison noted that many of the parkways and state highways his department is responsible for are very old. The path of Route 9, for example, has existed since before the Revolution and the trees bordering it tend to be quite old. He says residents often complain as crews are doing tree clearance along stretches of highway and parkway.
 ''The trees are old, and people don't want them to be taken down,'' Mr. Dennison said. ''If they're a threat, our job is to convince them it's the right thing to do for the public good.''
 Yet the issue is always contentious, and it becomes only more so the farther one goes from major thoroughfares in Westchester. 
 Ask people what they like about the county and odds are good that green will be part of their answer. Green as in trees. Big ones, small ones, deciduous and coniferous, towering and drooping, scenting the air with their oxygen-rich perfume. It's no wonder that Joyce Kilmer never found a poem as lovely as a tree: he came from Larchmont, a town that even has a tree in its name. 
 Like-minded residents in Westchester today prize not only the beauty and environmental benefits of trees but also their gratifying effect on real estate prices. ''When people see a municipal truck cutting down a tree they typically get angry,'' Mr. Feiner, the Greenburgh supervisor, said. ''They feel it's an enhancement to the community.''
 Many a community battle has been waged over whether a given tree will succumb to development or be accommodated in new landscapes. At least 21 of 45 Westchester municipalities have ordinances regulating the removal of trees on private property, with some also covering them under historic preservation laws. And governments are often looking for new ways to protect them.
 In Somers, for example, officials are reviewing the effectiveness of tree protection legislation adopted only within the last year. That law requires a permit to cut down trees with trunks measuring more than eight inches in diameter, in buffer areas 20 feet from a property line. It also requires a permit for the felling of more than five trees anywhere, said Mary Beth Murphy, Somers supervisor. 
 But after reviewing the law, the town realized that it did not offer much protection for smaller trees like dogwoods; officials are now looking to strengthen the ordinance.
 Somers, a northern Westchester community relying on wells and septic systems, must also rely on trees to help maintain the natural environment that cleans the waters going into the reservoirs that supply drinking water, Ms. Murphy said. She also emphasized that the town is situated in the Croton Watershed and is serious about its role as a steward of that system. 
 Beyond that, trees are important in the town's efforts to retain its rural ambience in these days of relentless development.
 ''It's one of the charms that draw people here,'' Ms. Murphy said.
 Trees can also be a bonus for property values. As Mr. Cook of The Care of Trees put it: ''Trees to me are no different than your kitchen or bath. People look at them as an economic value that can add 10 to 15 percent to resale value.''
 He added that he had seen contracts drawn up to protect trees when pools were being installed or construction was being done on a neighboring lot. Typically, such contracts set penalties for disturbances to root systems. 
 But whether residents are spending $125 a year to have their trees inspected or many thousands to have them maintained, arborists describe an increasing overall awareness of trees' value.
 Bedford provides a good example. The town spends about $250,000 a year inspecting, treating and removing trees, as well as about $8,000 a year to protect the Bedford Oak, a massive gnarled specimen that has stood at the intersection of Cantitoe Street and Hook Road for 400 to 500 years, said Peter T. Michaelis, chairman of the town's tree advisory board. 
 With branches spreading out about 130 feet and a trunk some 18 feet in circumference, the Bedford Oak looks like something out of a fairy tale. A crutch was placed under its lowest branch to protect it from breaking off should someone sit on it, Mr. Michaelis said.
 ''Its strength and longevity have made it a symbol for the town,'' Mr. Michaelis said.
 On a smaller scale in Bedford, Maple Avenue residents are beginning to discuss replacing the street's namesake trees, which line the block.
 ''These trees are hitting the end of their lifetime and we're faced with a dilemma,'' Mr. Michaelis said. ''People are unhappy when they start to see an old tree come down and a sapling go up.''
 To get ahead of the curve, they are beginning to plant young maples before the others have to come down. 
 ''At least in northern Westchester,'' he concluded, ''we don't think of ourselves as a suburb, we think of ourselves as the country. And our trees are very emblematic of that.
 ''A tree can't come down in this community without someone saying, 'Oh, My God.''' 
 And Greenburgh isn't much different. It may be less rural than Bedford, but Mr. Seife is not the only Greenburgh resident who feels chagrined when a tree comes down. 
 About two weeks ago, Greenburgh residents converged on 42 Round Hill Road, not far from Mr. Seife's house, to express their concerns about tree removal to a new owner, his lawyer, arborist and landscape architect. The town board and supervisor were there, too. The site of the former Scarsdale gun club, the 1.3-acre property has gone untouched for some 75 years.
 Michael P. D'Alessio, the property owner, has proposed building a $2 million home with tennis court, swimming pool and pool house. Many trees too small to be covered by the town's tree ordinance -- those with trunks under six inches in diameter -- are already gone. Mr. D'Alessio's plans call for the removal of 61 of the 85 remaining mature trees.
 But the neighborhood is fighting the plan and has asked the town to limit the number further. The site visit was meant to give officials and neighbors a firsthand glimpse of what would go and what would stay. Mature trees had been numbered, and many of them were discussed at length.
 At times, tempers flared.
 Mark Weingarten, who is representing Mr. D'Alessio, asserted that the opposition was not really about the trees, but about not wanting his client to build on the property. He said he felt his client was being held to an unfairly high standard, citing next-door neighbors who 
 ''don't want these trees to come down because they don't have a single tree on their property.
 ''I look at the other side of the hedgerow,'' Mr. Weingarten said, ''and there is not a single tree.''
 The neighbor in question, Mark Kaplan, countered that Mr. D'Alessio had only one goal: to clear-cut the land for subdivision and full development. 
 Neighbors expressed fear that the developer's plans would so denude the land on the sloping lot that the character of the neighborhood would be forever changed and the downhill neighbors would suffer severe drainage problems. ''We passed a law in Greenburgh that says trees must be preserved,'' said Thomas J. Abinanti, a county legislator for the area and a lawyer representing concerned neighbors. ''If you want a Long Island-style development, go develop in Long Island. Keep the green in Greenburgh.''
 To the landscape architect and the arborist hired by Mr. D'Alessio, the scrutiny was not surprising. Over the years, they said they had become used to such debates.
 ''Trees are the most emotional thing in the world,'' said Mr. Buddingh, the arborist, whose Buddingh Tree business card carries the slogan ''Balancing the Needs of Trees and People.''
 ''The reality is, this is a building lot, and it's important you be allowed to build, and that means change,'' he said. ''Change just doesn't come easy.'' 

Many Losses, and a Survivor
 THE deaths of Stephen J. Spruck and Suzana Dedivanaj-Spruck in a traffic accident on the Saw Mill Parkway in April have made the life of their 7-month-old daughter, Kristina, all the more special.
 Kristina's survival, described as no less than a miracle by Msgr. Edward Barry as he eulogized the couple during services at St. Barnabas Church in the Bronx, has rallied her family to pull together to care for the little girl who came inches from death as a tree fell on the family's sport utility vehicle.
 Marie Spruck, her grandmother, said in a telephone interview that it was still too painful to go into detail about what had happened. She said the baby was staying with other family members and would remain in the family, though it was not clear which members would take custody. Peter A. Goldman, a family lawyer, said, ''Plans have been put in place to safeguard her future, and she will have as normal an upbringing as possible under the circumstances.'' 
 Hundreds turned out for the couple's funeral, including students of Suzana Dedivanaj-Spruck, who taught third and fifth grade at P.S. 8 in the Bronx. She was on still maternity leave at the time of the accident. Her husband was an accountant with KPMG, a financial services corporation.
 No decision has been made on whether to file a lawsuit, Mr. Goldman said.
 At least eight injury or fatal accidents involving falling trees or branches have been reported in Westchester County over the last 12 years. On Oct. 19, 1996, a Queens man was fatally injured on the Saw Mill when a tree toppled onto the roadway during a storm. Farther north on the parkway that same day, a 79-year-old Bedford Hills man was killed. 
 Many of the other accidents also occurred during storms. In 1997, a 20-year-old White Plains man was killed when a branch snapped in high winds and came through the windshield of his car on Route 22. In 1996, a Poughkeepsie man was killed when a large tree fell across three lanes of the Sprain Brook Parkway in Greenburgh during a snowstorm.
 In 1992, a 43-year-old Pelham Manor man, Frederick Guido, suffered permanent brain damage and blindness when a winter storm knocked a century-old oak tree onto his Jeep. 
 It was a still, sunny day in 1998 when a tree came down and killed William Hilliard, 51, as he and his wife, Selamawit, were driving on Central Park Avenue. Mrs. Hilliard was left a quadriplegic. Last year she won a $9 million settlement from Greenburgh. Cyrus M. Diamond, Mrs. Hilliard's lawyer, said that after a convalescence in a nursing home after the accident, she now lives in an apartment in Yonkers with full-time help. She has no memory of the accident, he said. Mr. Diamond said that if there was a message in the lawsuit, it was that towns need to make better use of trained arborists and conduct tree inspections.
